docs.title: 1. What Is CentOS?
docs.text:
CentOS (Community ENTerprise Operating System) is a free, open-source Linux distribution that is built from the same source code as Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL).

In simple terms:

  • RHEL → paid, enterprise support
  • CentOS → free, community version of RHEL

Because of this, CentOS is:

  • Very stable
  • Widely used on servers
  • Popular for learning Linux system administration

If you learn CentOS, you can easily work with RHEL and many cloud servers.

docs.title: 2.1 CentOS Linux (Traditional)
docs.text:
• Versions like CentOS 7
  • Very stable
  • Common in tutorials and older servers
  • CentOS 7 is still widely used

docs.title: 2.2 CentOS Stream (New Model)
docs.text:
• Rolling-release, sits between Fedora and RHEL
  • Receives updates earlier than RHEL
  • More “preview” style

👉 For beginners: If you see CentOS 7, it is perfectly fine to learn with it.

docs.title: 3. Where Is CentOS Used?
docs.text:
CentOS is mainly used in:

  • Web servers (Apache / Nginx)
  • Database servers (MySQL, PostgreSQL)
  • Big data (Hadoop, Spark)
  • DevOps / CI systems
  • Cloud & virtual machines

You usually do not install CentOS on laptops. It’s mostly used on servers or virtual machines.

docs.title: 1. What Is YUM?
docs.text:
YUM (Yellowdog Updater, Modified) is the package manager used in CentOS 7.

In simple words:

YUM helps you install, update, remove, and manage software automatically.

Instead of downloading .rpm files manually, YUM:

  • Downloads software from repositories
  • Resolves dependencies automatically
  • Keeps your system consistent and safe

docs.title: 2. What Is a Package?
docs.text:
A package is a software bundle that contains:

  • Program files
  • Libraries
  • Configuration files
  • Version information

In CentOS, packages are usually:

*.rpm

YUM works with RPM packages but you should use YUM, not rpm, in daily work.

docs.title: 3.1 Root Permission Required
docs.text:
Most YUM commands need root privileges:

sudo yum install vim

Or switch to root:

su -

docs.title: 4.1 Install a Package
docs.text:
sudo yum install vim

YUM will:

  1. Check repositories
  2. Resolve dependencies
  3. Ask for confirmation

Type y and press Enter.

# Install a new package and assume yes to all questions (also works with update, great for automated updates):
yum -y install package

docs.title: 4.2 Remove a Package
docs.text: sudo yum remove vim

docs.title: 4.3 Update All Packages
docs.text:
sudo yum update

Update a single package:

sudo yum update nginx

docs.title: 4.4 Search for a Package
docs.text: yum search nginx

docs.title: 4.5 Get Package Information
docs.text: yum info nginx

docs.title: 5.1 List Installed Packages
docs.text: yum list installed

docs.title: 5.2 List Available Packages
docs.text: yum list available

docs.title: 5.3 Check if a Package Is Installed
docs.text: yum list installed | grep nginx

docs.title: 6.1 What Is a Repository?
docs.text:
A repository (repo) is a server that stores:

  • Software packages
  • Metadata
  • Dependency information

YUM downloads software only from enabled repositories.

docs.title: 6.2 Repo Configuration Location
docs.text:
/etc/yum.repos.d/

Each file ends with:

.repo

Example:

CentOS-Base.repo

docs.title: 6.3 View Enabled Repositories
docs.text: yum repolist

docs.title: 7.1 EPEL Repository
docs.text:
EPEL (Extra Packages for Enterprise Linux) provides many useful tools.

Install EPEL:

sudo yum install epel-release

Then:

docs.text:

# 1. Backup original
mv CentOS-Base.repo CentOS-Base.repo.backup
# 2. Download new source
wget http://mirrors.aliyun.com/repo/Centos-7.repo
# 3. Set as default
mv Centos-7.repo CentOS-Base.repo

docs.text: sudo yum clean all

docs.text:
If you already have an .rpm file:

sudo yum install ./package.rpm

YUM will still handle dependencies (better than rpm -ivh).

docs.text: yum history

docs.title: 10.2 Undo a Transaction
docs.text:

docs.title: 11.1 List Groups
docs.text: yum group list

docs.title: 11.2 Install a Group
docs.text: sudo yum groupinstall "Development Tools"

docs.text:

  • DNS problem
  • Repo misconfiguration

docs.title: 12.2 Locked YUM Process
docs.text:

docs.title: 13. Best Practices for Beginners
docs.text: ✅ Use yum instead of rpm ✅ Update system regularly ✅ Install EPEL early ✅ Read confirmation messages carefully ❌ Don’t disable core repositories blindly

YUM helps you:

docs.title: 1. What is rpm?
docs.text:
rpm stands for RPM Package Manager.

It is a low-level package management tool used mainly on:

  • RHEL
  • CentOS
  • Rocky Linux
  • AlmaLinux
  • Fedora

rpm is used to:

  • Install .rpm software packages
  • Query package information
  • Verify installed packages
  • Remove packages

📌 rpm works directly with local .rpm files It does NOT automatically resolve dependencies.

docs.title: 2. What Is an RPM Package?
docs.text:
An RPM package is a file like:

httpd-2.4.57-1.el9.x86_64.rpm

It contains:

  • Compiled binaries
  • Configuration files
  • Metadata (version, dependencies, description)
  • Scripts (pre/post install)

docs.title: 3. Basic Syntax
docs.text:
rpm [options] package

Examples:

rpm -ivh package.rpm
rpm -qa
rpm -qi bash

docs.title: 4.1 Install from a Local File (-i)
docs.text:
rpm -ivh httpd.rpm

Options:

  • -i → install
  • -v → verbose
  • -h → progress bar

docs.title: 4.2 Upgrade or Install (-U)
docs.text:
rpm -Uvh httpd.rpm

✔ Recommended over -i ✔ Upgrades if installed, installs if not

docs.title: 5. Remove an RPM Package
docs.text:
rpm -e httpd
  • -e → erase

Use package name, not file name.

docs.title: 6.1 List All Installed Packages
docs.text:
rpm -qa

Options:

  • -q → query
  • -a → all

docs.title: 6.2 Query a Specific Package
docs.text: rpm -qi bash

docs.title: 6.3 List Files Installed by a Package
docs.text: rpm -ql bash

docs.title: 6.4 Find Which Package Owns a File
docs.text: rpm -qf /bin/ls

docs.title: Package Info
docs.text: rpm -qip nginx.rpm

docs.title: List Files in an RPM File
docs.text: rpm -qlp nginx.rpm

docs.title: Show Required Dependencies
docs.text: rpm -qpR nginx.rpm

docs.title: Show What a Package Provides
docs.text: rpm -q --provides bash

docs.title: 9. Verify Installed Packages
docs.text:
rpm -V bash

Checks:

  • File size
  • Permissions
  • Ownership
  • Checksum

No output = everything OK.

docs.title: 10. Common rpm Options Summary
docs.text: Option Meaning -i Install -U Upgrade or install -e erase -q query -a all packages -l List files -f File owner -p Query RPM file -V Verify -h Progress bar

docs.title: Install Software from RPM
docs.text:
rpm -Uvh app.rpm

If dependency error appears:

failed dependencies:

➡️ Use yum / dnf instead.

docs.title: Check Installation
docs.text:
rpm -qi app
rpm -ql app

docs.title: Remove Software
docs.text: rpm -e app

docs.title: 12. rpm vs yum / dnf
docs.text:
Feature rpm yum / dnf Dependency resolution ❌ No ✅ Yes Install from repo ❌ No ✅ Yes Install local file ✅ Yes ✅ Yes Low-level control ✅ Yes ❌ Limited

📌 Use rpm to inspect packages 📌 Use yum / dnf to install software

docs.text: rpm -e httpd.rpm   # WRONG

docs.title: ✅ Correct
docs.text: rpm -e httpd

docs.title: ❌ Ignoring Dependencies
docs.text:

docs.text: rpm -q openssh

docs.title: Find Config Files
docs.text: rpm -qc httpd

docs.title: Find Documentation Files
docs.text: rpm -qd bash

docs.title: 15. Quick Cheat Sheet
docs.text:
rpm -qa
rpm -qi pkg
rpm -ql pkg
rpm -qf file
rpm -Uvh pkg.rpm
rpm -e pkg --nodeps

docs.title: 16. Summary
docs.text:
• rpm is a low-level package manager
  • Works with .rpm files
  • Does not resolve dependencies
  • Best used for querying and inspecting packages
  • Prefer yum / dnf for real installations

docs.title: 1. What Is /etc/profile.d/?
docs.text:
/etc/profile.d/ is a directory that contains shell scripts.

These scripts are:

  • Automatically executed when a user logs in
  • Applied system-wide (for all users)
  • Used to set environment variables, PATH, aliases, etc.

📌 In CentOS (and RHEL-based systems), /etc/profile.d/ is sourced by /etc/profile.

docs.title: 2. When Are Scripts in /etc/profile.d/ Executed?
docs.text:
For login shells, the execution order is roughly:

  1. /etc/profile
  2. All *.sh scripts in /etc/profile.d/
  3. User’s ~/.bash_profile (or ~/.bash_login, ~/.profile)

So:

/etc/profile.d/*.sh runs before user-specific config

docs.title: 3. Why /etc/profile.d/ Exists
docs.text:
Without /etc/profile.d/, all system-wide settings would have to be placed in one file:

/etc/profile

That would be messy.

Instead:

  • Each application adds its own script
  • Configuration is modular and clean

Examples:

  • java.sh
  • maven.sh
  • go.sh

docs.title: 4. What Kind of Files Go in /etc/profile.d/?
✔ Allowed
docs.text:
• Shell scripts (.sh)
  • Environment variable definitions
  • PATH updates
  • Aliases and functions

docs.title: ❌ Not Recommended
docs.text:
• Heavy logic
  • Long-running commands
  • Interactive commands (read, vim, echo spam)

docs.title: 5. File Naming Rules
docs.text:
• Must end with .sh
  • Must be readable
  • Usually owned by root

Example:

/etc/profile.d/java.sh

docs.title: 6.1 Create Script (Root Required)
docs.text:
sudo vim /etc/profile.d/java.sh
export JAVA_HOME=/usr/lib/jvm/java-17
export PATH=$JAVA_HOME/bin:$PATH

docs.title: 6.2 Apply Changes
docs.text:
Log out and log in again, or:

source /etc/profile

Check:

echo $JAVA_HOME
java -version

docs.title: 7. Example: Add a Custom PATH
docs.text:
sudo vim /etc/profile.d/tools.sh
export PATH=/opt/tools/bin:$PATH

docs.title: 8. Example: Define Aliases
docs.text:
sudo vim /etc/profile.d/aliases.sh
alias ll='ls -lh'
alias gs='git status'

After login:

ll
gs

docs.title: 9. Which Shells Use /etc/profile.d/?
docs.text:
Shell Supported bash ✅ Yes sh ✅ Yes zsh ❌ No (by default) fish ❌ No

📌 /etc/profile.d/ works only for shells that read /etc/profile.

docs.title: Login Shell (Works)
docs.text:
ssh user@host
su - user

docs.title: Non-Login Shell (Does NOT run /etc/profile.d/)
docs.text:
bash

To apply settings:

source /etc/profile

docs.title: 11. /etc/profile.d/ vs Other Config Files
docs.text: File Scope /etc/profile System-wide, login /etc/profile.d/*.sh System-wide, modular ~/.bash_profile User login ~/.bashrc Interactive shell /etc/bashrc System-wide interactive

docs.title: ❌ Forgetting .sh Extension
docs.text:
java

Script won’t be loaded.

docs.title: ❌ Using echo or read
docs.text:
echo "Welcome"
read name

Breaks login experience.

docs.title: ❌ Overwriting PATH
docs.text: export PATH=/my/bin

docs.title: ✅ Correct
docs.text: export PATH=/my/bin:$PATH

docs.title: Check Which Scripts Are Loaded
docs.text: ls /etc/profile.d/

docs.title: Manually Test Script
docs.text: source /etc/profile.d/java.sh

docs.title: Check Login Shell
docs.text: echo $0

docs.title: 14. Practical Use Cases
docs.text:
• System-wide Java / Maven / Go setup
  • Company-wide environment variables
  • Teaching lab environments
  • Shared servers

docs.title: 15. Summary
docs.text:
• /etc/profile.d/ stores system-wide login shell scripts
  • Files must end with .sh
  • Executed for all users
  • Best place for global environment variables
  • Cleaner than editing /etc/profile directly

docs.text: Understanding Network Services in CentOS

docs.title: 1. What Are “Network Services”?
docs.text:
In CentOS, a network service is a background program (daemon) that:

  • Manages network connections
  • Provides network functionality
  • Starts automatically in the background

Examples:

  • network → basic network interface management
  • NetworkManager → dynamic network management
  • sshd → SSH remote login
  • firewalld → firewall service

docs.title: 2. Service Management Basics (systemd)
docs.text: CentOS 7 uses systemd to manage services.

docs.title: 2.1 Common systemctl Commands
docs.text:
systemctl status service_name
systemctl start service_name
systemctl stop service_name
systemctl restart service_name
systemctl enable service_name
systemctl disable service_name

Example:

sudo systemctl status network

docs.title: 3.1 What Is the network Service?
docs.text:
The network service:

  • Reads configuration files from /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/
  • Brings interfaces up or down
  • Uses files like ifcfg-ens33

Service name:

network

docs.title: 3.2 Check Network Service Status
docs.text: systemctl status network

docs.title: 3.3 Restart Network Service
docs.text:
sudo systemctl restart network

⚠️ Restarting the network service may disconnect SSH.

docs.title: 4.1 What Is NetworkManager?
docs.text:
NetworkManager is a more advanced network service that:

  • Supports Wi-Fi, VPN, mobile networks
  • Handles dynamic network changes
  • Is enabled by default in many systems

Service name:

NetworkManager

docs.title: 4.2 Check NetworkManager Status
docs.text: systemctl status NetworkManager

docs.title: 4.3 NetworkManager Tools
docs.text:
Tool Purpose nmcli Command-line management nmtui Text-based UI

Example:

nmtui

docs.title: 5. network vs NetworkManager
docs.text:
Item network NetworkManager Config style ifcfg files dynamic Server usage Common Common Desktop usage Rare Common DHCP support Yes Yes Recommended for beginners Yes Yes

⚠️ Do not manage the same interface with both at the same time.

docs.title: 6.1 What Is SSH?
docs.text:
SSH allows you to:

  • Log in remotely
  • Execute commands securely

Service name:

sshd

docs.title: 6.2 Check SSH Service
docs.text:
systemctl status sshd

Start SSH:

sudo systemctl start sshd
sudo systemctl enable sshd

docs.title: 7.1 What Is firewalld?
docs.text:
firewalld controls:

  • Which ports are open
  • Which services are allowed

Service name:

firewalld

docs.title: 7.2 Check Firewall Status
docs.text: systemctl status firewalld

docs.title: 7.3 Allow SSH Traffic
docs.text:
sudo firewall-cmd --add-service=ssh --permanent
sudo firewall-cmd --reload

docs.title: 8.1 /etc/resolv.conf
docs.text:
Used for DNS:

cat /etc/resolv.conf

Example:

nameserver 8.8.8.8

This file is often managed automatically.

docs.title: 8.2 Name Service Switch (nsswitch.conf)
docs.text:
/etc/nsswitch.conf

Controls how the system resolves:

  • hostnames

docs.title: CentOS: ens33
docs.text: Understanding /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-ens33

docs.title: 1. What Is ifcfg-ens33?
docs.text:
In CentOS 7, network interfaces are configured using files located in:

/etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/

Each network interface has one configuration file:

ifcfg-<interface-name>

Example:

ifcfg-ens33

This file controls:

  • IP address
  • DHCP or static IP
  • Gateway
  • DNS
  • Whether the network starts at boot

docs.title: 2. What Is ens33?
docs.text:
ens33 is the network interface name.

Modern Linux uses predictable network interface names:

Name Meaning ens33 Ethernet + slot number eth0 Old-style naming lo Loopback interface

To list interfaces:

ip addr

docs.title: 3. When Is ifcfg-ens33 Used?
docs.text:
ifcfg-ens33 is used when:

  • CentOS boots
  • Network service restarts
  • Interface is brought up manually

The network service reads this file and configures the interface accordingly.

docs.title: 4. Typical ifcfg-ens33 File Example
docs.text:
TYPE=Ethernet
BOOTPROTO=dhcp
NAME=ens33
DEVICE=ens33
ONBOOT=yes

This is a DHCP-based configuration.

docs.title: 5.1 TYPE
docs.text:
TYPE=Ethernet
  • Network type
  • Usually Ethernet

docs.title: 5.2 BOOTPROTO
docs.text:
BOOTPROTO=dhcp

Controls how IP is obtained:

Value Meaning dhcp Automatically get IP none Static IP static Same as none

docs.title: 5.3 DEVICE
docs.text:
DEVICE=ens33
  • Interface name
  • Must match the real interface name

docs.title: 5.4 NAME
docs.text:
NAME=ens33
  • Human-readable name
  • Usually same as DEVICE

docs.title: 5.5 ONBOOT
docs.text:
ONBOOT=yes
  • Whether the interface starts at boot
  • yes is recommended for servers

docs.title: 6. Static IP Configuration (Very Important)
docs.text:
Example of a static IP configuration:

TYPE=Ethernet
BOOTPROTO=none
NAME=ens33
DEVICE=ens33
ONBOOT=yes

IPADDR=192.168.1.100
PREFIX=24
GATEWAY=192.168.1.1
DNS1=8.8.8.8
DNS2=1.1.1.1

docs.title: 7.1 IPADDR
docs.text:
IPADDR=192.168.1.100
  • The server’s IP address
  • Set this to your specific machine's IP

docs.title: 7.2 PREFIX
docs.text:
PREFIX=24
  • Subnet mask in CIDR format
  • 24 = 255.255.255.0

docs.title: 7.3 GATEWAY
docs.text:
GATEWAY=192.168.1.1
  • Default gateway
  • Required for internet access

docs.title: 7.4 DNS1, DNS2
docs.text:
DNS1=8.8.8.8
DNS2=1.1.1.1
  • DNS servers
  • Used for domain name resolution

docs.title: 8. Restart Network After Editing
docs.text:
After editing the file, restart the network:

sudo systemctl restart network

Or bring the interface down and up:

sudo ifdown ens33
sudo ifup ens33

docs.title: 9. How to Edit the File Safely
docs.text:
Use a text editor:

sudo vi /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-ens33

Before editing, make a backup:

sudo cp ifcfg-ens33 ifcfg-ens33.bak

docs.title: 10. Common Beginner Mistakes
docs.text: ❌ Interface name does not match ❌ ONBOOT=no ❌ Wrong gateway ❌ IP conflict on the network ❌ Forgetting to restart network

docs.title: 11. How to Check If It Works
11.1 Check IP
docs.text: ip addr show ens33

docs.title: 11.2 Check Routing
docs.text: ip route

docs.title: 11.3 Test Internet
docs.text:
ping 8.8.8.8
ping google.com

docs.title: 12. DHCP vs Static IP (Quick Comparison)
docs.text: Item DHCP Static IP assignment Automatic Manual Easy to use Yes No Server recommended No Yes Risk of IP change Yes No

docs.title: 13. Important Note (CentOS 8+)
docs.text:
In CentOS 8 and later:

  • network-scripts is deprecated
  • NetworkManager is used instead
  • Tools: nmcli, nmtui

But CentOS 7 still widely uses ifcfg-\* files.

docs.title: 14. Summary
docs.text:
• ifcfg-ens33 defines network settings for ens33
  • Located in /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/
  • Controls DHCP, static IP, DNS, gateway
  • Changes require network restart

If you understand this file, you understand basic Linux networking 👍

docs.title: CentOS: Hosts
docs.text: Understanding /etc/hosts

docs.title: 1. What Is /etc/hosts?
docs.text:
/etc/hosts is a local hostname resolution file.

In simple words:

It maps IP addresses to hostnames before the system asks a DNS server.

When your system tries to access a hostname (for example example.com), it:

  1. Checks /etc/hosts
  2. If not found, queries DNS

docs.title: 2. Why Does /etc/hosts Exist?
docs.text:
/etc/hosts is used for:

  • Quick hostname resolution
  • Testing without DNS
  • Local development
  • Temporary overrides
  • Small internal networks

It works without internet access.

docs.title: 3. Where Is /etc/hosts Located?
docs.text:
/etc/hosts

It is a plain text file.

docs.title: 4. Typical /etc/hosts File Example
docs.text:
127.0.0.1   localhost localhost.localdomain
::1         localhost localhost.localdomain

192.168.1.10  webserver
192.168.1.20  dbserver

docs.title: 5. Basic Format of /etc/hosts
docs.text:
Each line follows this format:

IP_address   hostname [alias1 alias2 ...]

Important rules:

  • Fields are separated by spaces or tabs
  • One IP can map to multiple names
  • Lines starting with # are comments

docs.title: 6.1 Loopback Address
docs.text:
127.0.0.1 localhost
  • Refers to your own machine
  • Used for local services

IPv6 equivalent:

::1 localhost

docs.title: 7. How /etc/hosts Works (Order Matters)
docs.text:
Linux hostname resolution order is defined in:

/etc/nsswitch.conf

Typical entry:

hosts: files dns

Meaning:

  1. files → /etc/hosts
  2. dns → DNS servers

So /etc/hosts overrides DNS.

docs.title: 8.1 Access a Server by Name
docs.text:
Instead of:

ssh 192.168.1.10

Use:

ssh webserver

docs.title: 8.2 Local Testing
docs.text:
127.0.0.1 mytest.com

Now:

ping mytest.com

resolves to 127.0.0.1.

docs.title: 8.3 Block a Website (Simple Trick)
docs.text:
127.0.0.1 facebook.com

The site will no longer load properly.

docs.title: 9. How to Edit /etc/hosts
docs.text: You need root privileges.

docs.title: 9.1 Edit with Vim
docs.text: sudo vi /etc/hosts

docs.title: 9.2 Backup First (Recommended)
docs.text: sudo cp /etc/hosts /etc/hosts.bak

docs.title: 10. Do Changes Take Effect Immediately?
docs.text:
Yes ✅

No restart is needed. Changes apply immediately.

Test with:

ping hostname

docs.title: 11. Common Beginner Mistakes
docs.text:
❌ Typing wrong IP address ❌ Forgetting to save the file ❌ Using tabs inconsistently (spaces are fine) ❌ Expecting /etc/hosts to work across multiple machines

Remember:

/etc/hosts works only on the local machine.

docs.title: 12. /etc/hosts vs DNS (Quick Comparison)
docs.text: Item /etc/hosts DNS Scope Local Network-wide Easy to edit Yes No Scalable No Yes Common usage Testing Production

docs.title: 13. Security Note
docs.text:
• /etc/hosts can be abused by malware
  • Always review it if network behavior looks strange

Check file permissions:

ls -l /etc/hosts

docs.title: 14. Summary
docs.text:
• /etc/hosts maps IPs to names locally
  • Checked before DNS
  • Simple and powerful
  • Best for testing and small setups

If you understand /etc/hosts, you understand basic hostname resolution 👍

docs.title: RPM & yum
docs.text:
• Package Management Tool
  • RPM (Red Hat Package Manager, for Red Hat, CentOS, Fedora): yum (.rpm)
  • Debian system (like ubuntu): apt-get

docs.title: 1.1 RPM WHAT？
docs.text:
• RPM 是一种标准化的软件包管理格式和软件包管理工具。
  • 目的：提供一种标准的方式来打包、分发和安装软件。
  • 原理：RPM 包是一个存档文件，将软件及其相关文件、配置信息、依赖关系等打包成一个单独的RPM包，以 .rpm 为文件扩展名。
  • 意义：它使得在支持RPM的Linux发行版上安装、管理和分发软件变得更加方便和可靠。
  • 缺点：RPM 可以定义软件包之间的依赖关系，但不能解决软件包依赖性问题。

docs.title: 1.2 WHERE?
docs.text:
• Rpmfind

??? RPM包在Linux系统中常见的架构标识 * x86_64：表示64位x86架构，适用于使用64位处理器的计算机。 * i386、i686：表示32位x86架构，适用于使用32位处理器的计算机。 * armv6hl、armv7hl、aarch64：这些是ARM架构的不同变体。armv6hl适用于较旧的ARMv6架构，armv7hl适用于支持ARMv7指令集的设备，而aarch64适用于64位ARM架构。 * ppc64le：表示IBM Power架构的64位低能耗变体，适用于POWER8和POWER9处理器。 * s390x：表示IBM System z架构的64位变体，适用于IBM的大型机和主机系统。

  除了上述常见的架构标识外，还有一些其他特定架构的标识，如mips、mipsel、sparc等，它们在特定的硬件平台上使用。

  这些架构标识有助于确保选择适用于特定计算机架构的正确软件包，以确保兼容性和性能。

docs.title: 1.3 HOW?
docs.text:
# rpm
# RPM Package Manager.
# tags: [ packaging ]
# ---
# Show version of httpd package:
$ rpm -q httpd # (1)
# To install a package:
$ rpm -ivh <rpm> # (2)
# To remove a package:
$ rpm -e <package> # (3)

# For equivalent commands in other package managers, see <https://wiki.archlinux.org/title/Pacman/Rosetta>.
# More information: <https://rpm.org/>.
  1. q - query
  2. i - install; v - verbose; h - hash
  3. e - erase

docs.title: 2. yum
docs.text: Yum（Yellowdog Updater, Modified）是一个在Linux系统中常用的软件包管理工具，它可以帮助用户轻松地安装、更新和删除软件包。

docs.title: 2.1 yum WHAT？
docs.text:
• 基于 RPM 的简化软件包管理的工具。
  • 最初是为 Fedora 发行版开发的，现在也被许多其他 Linux 发行版所采用。
  • 会自动处理软件包之间的依赖关系，确保所需的其他软件包也会被正确地安装和配置。
  • 可以从预先配置的软件仓库中获取软件包。

docs.title: 2.2 HOW?
docs.text:
# yum
# Package management utility for RHEL, Fedora, and CentOS (for older versions).
# ---
# tags: [ packaging ]
# ---

# 准备工作
$ yum clean all
$ yum makecache
# Upgrade installed packages to the newest available versions:
$ yum upgrade

# To search for a package: 匹配名称和简介来搜索
$ yum search <package>

# 安装、更新、删除
# To install the latest version of a new package:
$ yum install <package> <package> <...>
# Install a new package and assume yes to all questions (also works with update, great for automated updates):
$ yum -y install package
# -y, --yes: 自动模式，对所有的提问都回答 yes
$ yum update <package>
# To remove a package:
$ yum remove <package>

# 描述和简介信息
# List packages matching <phrase>:
$ yum list <phrase>
$ yum list installed # 显示已装的软件包
$ yum list available # 显示可装（但未装）的软件包
# To find the dependencies of a package: 列出所有依赖关系
yum deplist <package>

# To find information about a package:
$ yum info <package>

# For equivalent commands in other package managers, see <https://wiki.archlinux.org/title/Pacman/Rosetta>.
# More information: <https://manned.org/yum>.

docs.title: 2.3 yum 的工作原理
docs.text:
• 软件仓库：提供软件包索引、信息（以供查询）和软件包（以供下载）

    Yum 通过与软件仓库进行交互来获取软件包信息。软件仓库是存储了大量软件包及其相关信息的服务器，用户可以从中获取需要的软件包。

  • 依赖解决：Yum 能够处理软件包之间的依赖关系。当用户安装一个软件包时，Yum 会自动检查并解决其所依赖的其他软件包。它会查找并安装所需的依赖包，以确保软件包能够正常运行。

  • 本地缓存：Yum 会在本地系统上建立一个缓存，将软件包的信息和文件保存在本地，利用本地缓存提高性能。这样，当用户再次需要同一软件包时，Yum 可以直接从本地缓存中获取，而无需再次从网络上下载。

  • 仓库配置：用户可以配置 Yum 以使用特定的软件仓库。配置文件中包含了软件仓库的地址、存储库的设置、软件包的优先级等信息。

docs.title: 2.4 配置 yum 的软件仓库
2.4.1 yum 常用的软件仓库及其介绍
2.4.2 CentOS 官方软件源特点
docs.text:
1. 不包括有版权争议的软件
  2. 软件包比较老旧
  3. 没有 eclipse、mplayer

docs.title: 2.4.2 /etc/yum.repos.d/
docs.text:
/etc 目录: 存放系统配置文件。

/etc/yum.repos.d/ 目录: 专门用于存放 Yum 软件仓库的配置文件。

配置文件命名规则：每个 Yum 软件仓库都有一个对应的配置文件，通常以 .repo 扩展名结尾。配置文件的命名规则一般为 <仓库名称>.repo，其中 <仓库名称> 是自定义的仓库标识符。

文件内容：每个配置文件包含仓库的名称、URL、GPG密钥、软件包信息等。这些信息定义了如何获取软件包、软件包的来源、安全验证等。配置文件使用INI格式，包括段落（section）和键值对（key-value）的形式。

多仓库支持：可以在 /etc/yum.repos.d/ 目录下配置多个仓库的配置文件，每个配置文件代表一个不同的软件仓库。这样可以方便地管理和切换不同的软件源，以获取所需的软件包。

管理方式：可以通过创建、编辑或删除 /etc/yum.repos.d/ 目录下的配置文件来管理 Yum 软件仓库。

$ cd /etc/yum.repos.d/
$ yum install yum-plugin-priorities

docs.title: Shell Proxy
docs.text: (Terminal / Command-Line Proxy Explained Simply)

docs.title: 1. What Is a Shell Proxy?
docs.text:
A shell proxy means routing network traffic from command-line tools through a proxy server.

Instead of your terminal tools (like curl, git, apt, brew, pip) connecting directly to the internet, they go through:

Terminal App → Proxy Server → Internet

This is useful when:

  • You are behind a firewall
  • You need to bypass network restrictions
  • You want faster or safer access to the internet
  • You already use tools like Clash / Shadowsocks / V2Ray / Surge

docs.title: 2. What Tools Are Affected by Shell Proxy?
docs.text:
Once enabled, many CLI tools automatically follow proxy settings, including:

  • curl, wget
  • git
  • apt, yum, dnf, pacman
  • pip, npm, yarn
  • brew
  • docker (partially)

docs.title: 3. Common Proxy Types
docs.text:
Type Example HTTP Proxy http://127.0.0.1:7890 HTTPS Proxy http://127.0.0.1:7890 SOCKS5 Proxy socks5://127.0.0.1:7891

⚠️ Most modern proxy apps provide SOCKS5 and HTTP ports.

docs.title: 4. Typical Local Proxy Apps & Ports
docs.text:
App HTTP Port SOCKS5 Port Clash 7890 7891 Surge 6152 6153 Shadowsocks 1080 1080 V2Ray 10809 10808

You only need one correct port.

docs.title: HTTP / HTTPS Proxy
docs.text:
export http_proxy="http://127.0.0.1:7890"
export https_proxy="http://127.0.0.1:7890"

docs.title: SOCKS5 Proxy
docs.text:
export all_proxy="socks5://127.0.0.1:7891"

These settings disappear when you close the terminal 👍

docs.title: 5.2 Test If Proxy Works
docs.text:
curl ipinfo.io

If proxy is working:

  • IP ≠ your local ISP IP
  • Country may change

docs.title: 6. Disable Shell Proxy
docs.text:
unset http_proxy
unset https_proxy
unset all_proxy

Always remember this command. Many “network problems” are caused by forgotten proxy settings.

docs.title: 7.1 Zsh (macOS default)
docs.text:
Edit config:

nano ~/.zshrc

Add:

export http_proxy="http://127.0.0.1:7890"
export https_proxy="http://127.0.0.1:7890"

Apply:

source ~/.zshrc

⚠️ Not recommended unless you always need proxy

docs.title: 8. Quick Toggle Scripts (Best Practice)
docs.text:
Add to ~/.zshrc:

proxy_on() {
  export http_proxy="http://127.0.0.1:7890"
  export https_proxy="http://127.0.0.1:7890"
  export all_proxy="socks5://127.0.0.1:7891"
  echo "Proxy ON"
}

proxy_off() {
  unset http_proxy
  unset https_proxy
  unset all_proxy
  echo "Proxy OFF"
}

Usage:

proxy_on
proxy_off

✔ Clean ✔ Safe ✔ Beginner-friendly

docs.title: Git
docs.text:
git config --global http.proxy http://127.0.0.1:7890
git config --global https.proxy http://127.0.0.1:7890

Remove:

git config --global --unset http.proxy
git config --global --unset https.proxy

docs.title: Docker
docs.text:
mkdir -p ~/.docker
nano ~/.docker/config.json
{
  "proxies": {
    "default": {
      "httpProxy": "http://127.0.0.1:7890",
      "httpsProxy": "http://127.0.0.1:7890"
    }
  }
}

Restart Docker.

docs.title: ❌ curl: (7) Failed to connect
docs.text:
• Proxy app not running
  • Wrong port

docs.title: ❌ Connection reset
docs.text:
• Try switching HTTP ↔ SOCKS5
  • Use:
curl --proxy socks5://127.0.0.1:7891 https://google.com

docs.title: ❌ Network suddenly broken
docs.text: proxy_off

docs.title: 11. Best Practices (Important!)
docs.text:
✔ Use temporary proxy ✔ Prefer SOCKS5 if available ✔ Always know how to disable ✔ Test with curl ipinfo.io

❌ Do NOT leave proxy permanently enabled unless necessary ❌ Do NOT mix multiple proxy tools

docs.title: 12. Mental Model (Remember This)
docs.text:
Shell proxy ≠ System proxy

  • System proxy → GUI apps (browser)
  • Shell proxy → Terminal tools only

If you want, I can next:

  • Explain SOCKS5 vs HTTP proxy deeply

Just tell me 👍

docs.title: 1. What is XDG?
docs.text:
XDG stands for X Desktop Group (now under freedesktop.org).

In simple terms:

XDG defines a set of standards that help Linux applications know where to store files and how to integrate with the desktop environment.

Before XDG, every application put files wherever it wanted, which led to chaos in $HOME. XDG brings order.

docs.title: 2. Why XDG Exists
docs.text:
Without XDG:

  • Config files scattered everywhere (~/.app1, ~/.config2, ~/random)
  • Cache files mixed with important data
  • Desktop menus inconsistent across environments

With XDG:

  • Predictable directories
  • Cleaner home directory
  • Desktop-agnostic behavior (works on GNOME, KDE, XFCE, etc.)

docs.title: 3. The Core Idea: XDG Base Directory Specification
docs.text: The XDG Base Directory Specification defines standard environment variables that applications should follow.

docs.title: The Most Important XDG Variables
docs.text:
Variable Purpose Default Location XDG_CONFIG_HOME User configuration files ~/.config XDG_DATA_HOME User data files ~/.local/share XDG_CACHE_HOME Cache files ~/.cache XDG_STATE_HOME State files (logs, history) ~/.local/state

If these variables are not set, applications must fall back to the defaults above.

docs.title: 4.1 Configuration → XDG_CONFIG_HOME
docs.text:
• Settings you want to keep
  • Human-readable
  • Safe to back up

Example:

~/.config/
 ├── git/config
 ├── nvim/init.lua
 └── alacritty/alacritty.yml

docs.title: 4.2 Data → XDG_DATA_HOME
docs.text:
• Persistent user data
  • Databases, icons, plugins

Example:

~/.local/share/
 ├── applications/
 ├── fonts/
 └── nvim/site/

docs.title: 4.3 Cache → XDG_CACHE_HOME
docs.text:
• Temporary data
  • Safe to delete

Example:

~/.cache/
 ├── pip/
 ├── thumbnails/
 └── chromium/

docs.title: 4.4 State → XDG_STATE_HOME
docs.text:
• Logs, history, runtime state
  • Not exactly config, not exactly cache

Example:

~/.local/state/
 ├── bash/history
 └── nvim/log

docs.title: 5. Viewing Your XDG Settings
docs.text:
Check current values:

echo $XDG_CONFIG_HOME
echo $XDG_DATA_HOME
echo $XDG_CACHE_HOME

If nothing prints, defaults are being used.

docs.title: 6. Setting XDG Variables (Optional)
docs.text:
You can customize XDG directories in your shell config:

# ~/.bashrc or ~/.zshrc
export XDG_CONFIG_HOME="$HOME/.config"
export XDG_DATA_HOME="$HOME/.local/share"
export XDG_CACHE_HOME="$HOME/.cache"
export XDG_STATE_HOME="$HOME/.local/state"

💡 Most users keep defaults — changing them is optional.

docs.title: Good Citizens (Follow XDG)
docs.text:
• git
  • neovim
  • systemd
  • pip
  • flatpak

docs.title: Bad / Legacy Apps
docs.text:
• Still write to ~/.appname
  • Ignore XDG variables

You’ll often see people migrate old dotfiles into ~/.config.

docs.title: 8. XDG Desktop Integration (Quick Intro)
docs.text: Beyond directories, XDG also defines:

docs.title: .desktop files
docs.text:
Used for application launchers.

Location:

~/.local/share/applications/

Example:

[Desktop Entry]
Name=My App
Exec=my-app
Type=Application

docs.title: MIME types & default apps
docs.text:
Managed via:

xdg-mime
xdg-open

Example:

xdg-open file.pdf

This opens the file using your system’s default app.

docs.title: 9. Common XDG Tools You’ll See
docs.text:
Command Purpose xdg-open Open file/URL with default app xdg-mime Query/set default applications xdg-user-dirs Manage Documents, Downloads, etc.

Example:

xdg-user-dir DOCUMENTS

docs.title: 10. Why XDG Matters to You
docs.text:
If you:

  • Manage dotfiles
  • Write Linux apps
  • Use multiple desktop environments
  • Care about clean $HOME

Then understanding XDG is essential.

docs.title: 11. One-Sentence Summary
docs.text: XDG is a Linux standard that tells applications where to store config, data, cache, and how to integrate with the desktop in a clean, predictable way.

docs.text: A Beginner’s Guide

docs.title: 1. Why So Many Linux Distributions?
docs.text:
Linux is a kernel, not a full operating system. Different communities and companies build distributions (distros) around it with different goals:

  • Stability
  • Ease of use
  • Enterprise support
  • Update speed

Ubuntu, CentOS, and Debian are three of the most common.

docs.title: 2. Quick Overview Table
docs.text: Feature Ubuntu Debian CentOS Base Debian Independent Red Hat Enterprise Linux Target users Beginners, developers Stability-focused users Servers, enterprise Package manager apt apt dnf / yum Release style Time-based Stability-based Enterprise-style Default desktop GNOME None / optional None Ease of use ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ ⭐⭐⭐ ⭐⭐ Server popularity Very high High Very high

docs.title: 3.1 What Is Debian?
docs.text:
Debian is one of the oldest Linux distributions and is famous for:

  • Rock-solid stability
  • Strong community governance
  • Very strict software policies

Many distros are built on top of Debian, including Ubuntu.

docs.title: 3.2 Debian Release Branches
docs.text:
Branch Description Stable Very reliable, older software Testing Newer packages, less tested Unstable Rolling, developers only

👉 Beginners usually use Stable.

docs.title: 3.3 Pros & Cons of Debian
docs.text:
Pros

  • Extremely stable
  • Minimal and clean
  • Long-term reliability

Cons

  • Software versions can be old
  • More manual setup
  • Less beginner-friendly UI

docs.title: 4.1 What Is Ubuntu?
docs.text:
Ubuntu is based on Debian, but aims to be:

  • Easier to use
  • Faster to set up
  • More modern

It is maintained by Canonical.

docs.title: 4.2 Why Ubuntu Is Popular
docs.text:
• Easy installer
  • Good hardware support
  • Frequent updates
  • Strong documentation

Ubuntu focuses on usability + stability.

docs.title: 4.3 Ubuntu LTS
docs.text:
Ubuntu’s LTS (Long Term Support) releases:

  • 5 years of updates
  • Recommended for beginners and servers

Example:

  • Ubuntu 22.04 LTS

docs.title: 4.4 Pros & Cons of Ubuntu
docs.text:
Pros

  • Beginner-friendly
  • Modern software
  • Huge community
  • Great cloud support

Cons

  • Slightly heavier than Debian
  • Snap packages are controversial

docs.title: 5.1 What Is CentOS?
docs.text:
CentOS was traditionally a free rebuild of Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL).

It focuses on:

  • Enterprise stability
  • Long-term support
  • Server workloads

docs.title: 5.2 CentOS Stream (Important!)
docs.text:
CentOS has changed:

Old New CentOS Linux ❌ discontinued CentOS Stream ✅ current

CentOS Stream sits:

Fedora → CentOS Stream → RHEL

It is rolling-preview, not a clone anymore.

docs.title: 5.3 Pros & Cons of CentOS
docs.text:
Pros

  • Enterprise-style environment
  • RHEL compatibility
  • Long lifecycle concepts

Cons

  • Not beginner-friendly
  • Older software
  • CentOS Stream may be confusing

docs.title: 6. Package Management Comparison
docs.text:
Distro Command Ubuntu apt install nginx Debian apt install nginx CentOS dnf install nginx

Key difference:

  • Debian/Ubuntu → .deb
  • CentOS/RHEL → .rpm

docs.title: 7. Configuration Style Differences
docs.text: Area Ubuntu / Debian CentOS Network Netplan / NetworkManager NetworkManager Firewall ufw firewalld SELinux Disabled by default Enabled Config style Simple Enterprise-oriented

docs.title: 8.1 Choose Ubuntu If:
docs.text:

  • You want desktop + server
  • You use cloud, Docker, WSL
  • You want fast setup

✅ Best beginner choice

docs.title: 8.2 Choose Debian If:
docs.text:

  • You are comfortable with Linux

docs.title: 8.3 Choose CentOS If:
docs.text:

  • You need RHEL-like environments

docs.title: 9. Simple Mental Model
docs.text:
Debian  →  Ubuntu  →  User-friendly Linux
RHEL    →  CentOS  →  Enterprise Linux

docs.title: 10. Beginner Recommendation
docs.text:
For most beginners:

  1. Start with Ubuntu LTS
  2. Learn basic Linux commands
  3. Try Debian later for stability
  4. Learn CentOS if you work with servers

docs.title: Firewall
docs.text: (with PowerShell examples)

docs.title: 1. What Is Windows Firewall?
docs.text:
Windows Defender Firewall is a built-in security feature of Windows that:

  • Controls which programs or ports can send or receive network traffic
  • Protects your computer from unauthorized access
  • Works automatically in the background, but can be customized

Think of it as a gatekeeper:

  • ❌ Blocks unwanted traffic
  • ✅ Allows trusted traffic

docs.title: 2. Key Firewall Concepts (Very Important)
docs.text: Before touching commands, understand these basics:

docs.title: 2.1 Inbound vs Outbound
docs.text:
Direction Meaning Inbound Traffic coming into your computer Outbound Traffic going out from your computer

👉 Most security risks come from inbound connections, so firewall rules often focus there.

docs.title: 2.2 Ports
docs.text:
A port is like a door number for network traffic.

Common examples:

Port Service 22 SSH 80 HTTP 443 HTTPS 3389 Remote Desktop (RDP)

docs.title: 2.3 Protocols
docs.text:
Most rules use:

  • TCP – reliable, used by HTTP, SSH, RDP
  • UDP – faster, used by DNS, video streaming

docs.title: 2.4 Profiles
docs.text:
Windows Firewall applies rules based on network location:

Profile Used When Domain In a corporate domain Private Home or trusted network Public Coffee shop, airport (most restrictive)

docs.title: GUI (Beginner-friendly)
docs.text:
• Control Panel → Windows Defender Firewall
  • Advanced Settings → Inbound / Outbound Rules

docs.title: PowerShell (Professional & Scriptable)
docs.text:
• Faster
  • Repeatable
  • Ideal for servers and automation

👉 This tutorial focuses on PowerShell.

docs.title: 4. Check Firewall Status
docs.text:
Open PowerShell as Administrator, then run:

Get-NetFirewallProfile

You’ll see something like:

Name     : Public
Enabled  : True

This means the firewall is ON for that profile.

docs.title: List all rules
docs.text: Get-NetFirewallRule

docs.title: Find rules related to a program or port
docs.text: Get-NetFirewallRule | Select DisplayName, Enabled, Direction

docs.title: 6.1 Allow an Inbound TCP Port (Example: Port 8080)
docs.text:
New-NetFirewallRule `
  -DisplayName "Allow TCP 8080" `
  -Direction Inbound `
  -Protocol TCP `
  -LocalPort 8080 `
  -Action Allow

✅ This allows inbound traffic on port 8080.

docs.title: 6.2 Allow SSH (Port 22)
docs.text:
New-NetFirewallRule `
  -DisplayName "Allow SSH" `
  -Direction Inbound `
  -Protocol TCP `
  -LocalPort 22 `
  -Action Allow

docs.title: 6.3 Allow a Program Instead of a Port
docs.text:
Example: allow a specific app:

New-NetFirewallRule `
  -DisplayName "Allow My App" `
  -Direction Inbound `
  -Program "C:\MyApp\app.exe" `
  -Action Allow

👉 This is safer than opening a port globally.

docs.title: 7. Block Traffic (Yes, You Can Block Too)
Block inbound traffic on port 3306 (MySQL)
docs.text:
New-NetFirewallRule `
  -DisplayName "Block MySQL" `
  -Direction Inbound `
  -Protocol TCP `
  -LocalPort 3306 `
  -Action Block

docs.title: 8. Limit Rules to a Network Profile
docs.text:
Example: only allow SSH on Private networks:

New-NetFirewallRule `
  -DisplayName "Allow SSH Private" `
  -Direction Inbound `
  -Protocol TCP `
  -LocalPort 22 `
  -Profile Private `
  -Action Allow

🚫 SSH will NOT be accessible on Public networks.

docs.title: Disable a rule
docs.text: Disable-NetFirewallRule -DisplayName "Allow SSH"

docs.title: Enable it again
docs.text: Enable-NetFirewallRule -DisplayName "Allow SSH"

docs.title: Delete a rule
docs.text: Remove-NetFirewallRule -DisplayName "Allow SSH"

docs.title: 10. Common Beginner Mistakes
docs.text: ❌ Opening ports unnecessarily ❌ Allowing everything on Public profile ❌ Forgetting to run PowerShell as Administrator ❌ Using Any protocol when TCP/UDP is enough

docs.title: 11. Recommended Beginner Rule Pattern
docs.text:
A safe default template:

New-NetFirewallRule `
  -DisplayName "Allow Service Name" `
  -Direction Inbound `
  -Protocol TCP `
  -LocalPort <PORT> `
  -Profile Private `
  -Action Allow

docs.title: 12. When Should You Use PowerShell Firewall Rules?
docs.text:
• Setting up development servers
  • Enabling SSH / RDP / HTTP
  • Managing Windows Server
  • Automating security via scripts

docs.title: 13. Summary
docs.text:
• Windows Firewall controls network access
  • New-NetFirewallRule is the core command
  • Always:
    • Know which port
    • Know which direction
    • Limit to Private when possible

docs.title: 1. What is netsh?
docs.text:
netsh (Network Shell) is a built-in Windows command-line tool used to view, configure, and troubleshoot network settings.

You can use netsh to:

  • Configure IP addresses, DNS, gateways
  • Manage network interfaces
  • Set up port forwarding (portproxy)
  • View routing tables
  • Configure firewall and advanced networking features

Think of netsh as a command-line control panel for networking.

docs.title: 2. How netsh Works (Contexts)
docs.text:
netsh is context-based.

Basic structure:

netsh <context> <command> <parameters>

Examples:

netsh interface ip show config
netsh interface portproxy show all

Common contexts:

  • interface → Network interfaces (IP, DNS, ports)
  • interface ip → IPv4 settings
  • interface ipv6 → IPv6 settings
  • interface portproxy → Port forwarding
  • advfirewall → Windows Firewall (older alternative to PowerShell)

docs.title: 3. Entering Interactive Mode (Optional)
docs.text:
You can run netsh in interactive mode:

netsh

Prompt changes to:

netsh>

Then:

netsh> interface
netsh interface> ip
netsh interface ip> show config

To exit:

exit

Beginners usually prefer one-line commands, which we’ll use below.

docs.title: 4.1 List All Network Interfaces
docs.text:
netsh interface show interface

Output shows:

  • Interface name (e.g. Ethernet, Wi-Fi)
  • Status (Connected / Disconnected)
  • Type

docs.title: 4.2 Show IP Configuration
docs.text:
netsh interface ip show config

Equivalent to ipconfig /all, but more detailed and script-friendly.

docs.title: 4.3 Set a Static IP Address
docs.text:
netsh interface ip set address name="Ethernet" static 192.168.1.100 255.255.255.0 192.168.1.1

Parameters:

  • name="Ethernet" → Interface name
  • static → Static IP mode
  • 192.168.1.100 → IP address
  • 255.255.255.0 → Subnet mask
  • 192.168.1.1 → Default gateway

docs.title: 4.4 Switch Back to DHCP
docs.text:
netsh interface ip set address name="Ethernet" dhcp

Set DNS to automatic:

netsh interface ip set dns name="Ethernet" dhcp

docs.title: 4.5 Set DNS Manually
docs.text:
Primary DNS:

netsh interface ip set dns name="Ethernet" static 8.8.8.8

Secondary DNS:

netsh interface ip add dns name="Ethernet" 8.8.4.4 index=2

docs.title: 5.1 What Is portproxy?
docs.text:
portproxy allows Windows to:

  • Listen on a local port
  • Forward traffic to another IP and port

Typical use cases:

  • Forward Windows ports to WSL
  • Access Linux services from other machines
  • Redirect ports without installing extra software

It works at the TCP level, not application level.

docs.title: 5.2 Show Existing Port Forwarding Rules
docs.text: netsh interface portproxy show all

docs.title: 5.3 Add a Port Forwarding Rule
docs.text:
Example: Forward Windows port 8080 to 192.168.1.10:80

netsh interface portproxy add v4tov4 listenaddress=0.0.0.0 listenport=8080 connectaddress=192.168.1.10 connectport=80

Explanation:

  • v4tov4 → IPv4 to IPv4
  • listenaddress=0.0.0.0 → Listen on all local IPs
  • listenport=8080 → Local port
  • connectaddress=192.168.1.10 → Target IP
  • connectport=80 → Target port

docs.title: 5.4 Delete a Port Forwarding Rule
docs.text: netsh interface portproxy delete v4tov4 listenport=8080 listenaddress=0.0.0.0

docs.title: 5.5 Common Mistakes with portproxy
docs.text:
1. Firewall blocks the port

    netsh advfirewall firewall add rule name="PortProxy 8080" dir=in action=allow protocol=TCP localport=8080

  2. portproxy only supports TCP

    • ❌ UDP is not supported

  3. Service must be running on target machine

docs.title: 6.1 Show Routing Table
docs.text: netsh interface ip show route

docs.title: 6.2 Reset Network Stack (Troubleshooting)
docs.text:
Reset TCP/IP:

netsh int ip reset

Reset Winsock:

netsh winsock reset

(Usually followed by a reboot)

docs.title: 7. When to Use netsh vs PowerShell
docs.text:
Task Tool Legacy scripts netsh Port forwarding netsh portproxy Modern automation PowerShell (NetTCPIP) Firewall rules PowerShell (New-NetFirewallRule)

netsh is older but still essential, especially for port proxying.

docs.title: 8. Summary
docs.text:
• netsh is a powerful Windows networking CLI tool
  • Uses context-based commands
  • interface → IP, DNS, NIC management
  • portproxy → TCP port forwarding
  • Still widely used in servers, labs, WSL, and legacy environments

docs.title: 1. What is WSL?
docs.text:
WSL lets you run a Linux environment directly on Windows without a virtual machine. You can run Linux command-line tools, utilities, and applications natively, side by side with Windows.

  • No dual-boot needed.
  • No heavy VM overhead.
  • Ideal for developers, sysadmins, or anyone who needs Linux commands/tools on Windows.

There are two versions:

Version Features WSL 1 Uses a translation layer. Fast for file-heavy tasks in Windows filesystem. WSL 2 Uses a real Linux kernel inside a lightweight VM. Better compatibility and performance for Linux apps.

Tip: WSL 2 is recommended for most users.

docs.title: 2. Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Windows 10 (Version 2004 or later) or Windows 11.
  • Administrator privileges on your PC.
  • Internet connection to download Linux distributions.

docs.title: 3. Installing WSL
docs.text:
Open PowerShell as Administrator and run:

wsl --install

What this does:

  1. Enables WSL feature.
  2. Installs the WSL 2 kernel.
  3. Sets WSL 2 as default.
  4. Installs Ubuntu by default (can choose other distros later).

After installation, restart your PC if prompted.

docs.title: 4. Check WSL Installation
docs.text:
After reboot, open PowerShell (not necessarily as admin) and run:

wsl --list --verbose

Example output:

  NAME      STATE           VERSION
* Ubuntu    Running         2
  • VERSION 2 → WSL 2 is running.
  • STATE → whether your Linux distro is running.

docs.title: 5. Launching Linux
docs.text:
• Open Windows Terminal or PowerShell, type:
wsl
  • You’ll enter a Linux shell. Example:
user@DESKTOP:~$
  • Or, open Ubuntu from the Start Menu (installed distro appears as a Windows app).

docs.title: 6. Common WSL Commands
docs.text: Command Description wsl Launches default Linux distro. wsl -l -v Lists installed distros with version info. wsl --install -d <DistroName> Install a specific distro, e.g., wsl --install -d Debian. wsl --set-default-version 2 Set WSL 2 as default for new distros. wsl --unregister <DistroName> Uninstall a distro.

docs.title: 7. File System Access
docs.text:
• Windows drives in Linux:
cd /mnt/c
ls
  • Linux files from Windows: Open File Explorer and go to:
\\wsl$\Ubuntu\

This path shows your Linux filesystem.

docs.title: 8. Installing Linux Tools
docs.text:
Once inside WSL, you can use Linux package managers like apt:

sudo apt update        # Update package lists
sudo apt upgrade -y    # Upgrade installed packages
sudo apt install git   # Install Git

Works just like a normal Linux system.

docs.title: 9. Running Linux & Windows Together
docs.text:
• Run Windows apps from Linux:
notepad.exe
explorer.exe .
  • Run Linux commands from Windows PowerShell:
wsl ls -la

This lets you mix Linux and Windows workflows seamlessly.

docs.title: 10. Switching Between WSL Versions
docs.text:
Check current version:

wsl -l -v

Set a distro to WSL 2:

wsl --set-version Ubuntu 2

Set WSL 1 if needed:

wsl --set-version Ubuntu 1

docs.title: 11. Tips & Tricks
docs.text:
• Update WSL kernel manually:
wsl --update
  • Backup/Export a distro:
wsl --export Ubuntu ubuntu_backup.tar
  • Import a distro:
wsl --import UbuntuBackup C:\WSL\UbuntuBackup ubuntu_backup.tar --version 2
  • Use multiple distros: You can install Ubuntu, Debian, Fedora, etc., side by side.

docs.title: 12. Resources for Beginners
docs.text:
• Official WSL Docs
  • Windows Terminal for a better experience.
  • Tutorials on Linux basics (bash, vim, git) since WSL gives you the Linux shell.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
• WSL gives you Linux on Windows without a VM.
  • WSL 2 is recommended.
  • Linux tools, files, and Windows apps can work together seamlessly.
  • Easy to install, manage, and switch distros.

docs.title: 1. What is Asahi Linux?
docs.text:
Asahi Linux is a project aimed at porting Linux to Apple Silicon Macs (M1, M1 Pro, M1 Max, M2, etc.). It allows you to run Linux natively on these machines, taking advantage of their hardware while providing a fully functional Linux environment.

Key points:

  • Developed by the Asahi team, led by Hector Martin.
  • Focuses on Apple Silicon, which has a custom ARM64 architecture.
  • Supports GUI, terminal, GPU acceleration, and peripherals over time.
  • You can run it either natively on Mac hardware or dual-boot alongside macOS.

docs.title: 2. Supported Hardware
docs.text:
Asahi Linux primarily supports:

  • Apple Silicon Macs:
    • M1 MacBook Air / Pro
    • M1 Mac Mini
    • M1 iMac
    • M1 Mac Studio
    • M2 Macs (partial support)

Older Intel-based Macs are not the focus since they already run standard Linux well.

Tip: Check the official compatibility list before installing: Asahi Linux Supported Devices.

docs.title: 3. Installation Options
docs.text: There are two main ways to try Asahi Linux:

docs.title: Option 1: Native Install (Recommended)
docs.text:
• Replaces macOS entirely or sets up a dual-boot.
  • Best for those who want full Linux performance.

docs.title: Option 2: Virtual Machine
docs.text:
• Use UTM or Parallels to run Asahi Linux inside macOS.
  • Safer for beginners who don’t want to touch disk partitions.

docs.title: 4. Preparing Your Mac
docs.text:
Before installation:

  1. Backup macOS using Time Machine.

  2. Update macOS to the latest version.

  3. Free up space: You’ll need at least 20–30 GB for Asahi Linux.

  4. Check Apple Silicon model:

    system_profiler SPHardwareDataType

  5. Enable External Boot (optional for dual-boot):

    • Reboot → Hold Command + R → Utilities → Startup Security Utility → Allow booting from external media.

docs.title: Step 1: Boot into macOS Terminal
docs.text:
Open Terminal and run:

curl https://alx.sh | sh
  • This downloads the Asahi Linux installer.
  • The script will guide you through partitioning and installation.

docs.title: Step 2: Choose Installation Type
docs.text:
• Full Installation: Replaces macOS with Linux.
  • Dual Boot (Recommended): Installs Linux alongside macOS. The installer will automatically resize macOS partitions.

docs.title: Step 3: Configure Your System
docs.text:
• Select your preferred desktop environment (currently Asahi Linux supports GNOME by default).
  • Set your username and password.

docs.title: Step 4: Installation Process
docs.text:
• The installer downloads necessary packages and sets up your Linux root filesystem.
  • This may take 20–60 minutes depending on your internet speed.

docs.title: Step 5: Reboot
docs.text:
• After installation, reboot your Mac.
  • You will see a boot menu to choose macOS or Asahi Linux if dual-booting.

docs.title: 6. Post-Installation Tips
docs.text:
1. Update Your System

    sudo pacman -Syu

    Asahi Linux uses Arch Linux as its base.

  2. Install Basic Tools

    sudo pacman -S git vim htop

  3. GPU & Hardware Acceleration

    • M1 GPU support is integrated via Asahi Linux kernel.
    • Some features (e.g., full video acceleration) are still under development.

  4. Check System Info

lscpu             # CPU info
free -h           # Memory info
df -h             # Disk usage

Asahi Linux brings Linux to Apple Silicon Macs with good hardware support and growing software compatibility. Beginners should start with dual-boot, use the official installer, and gradually explore Linux tools and desktop environments.

docs.title: Net 01
docs.text: 在 macOS 上，可以通过以下常用命令行工具来查看网络状态与诊断问题。

docs.title: 一、查看网络接口与 IP 信息（最常用）
1️⃣ 查看所有网络接口
docs.text:
ifconfig
  • en0：通常是 Wi-Fi
  • en1 / en2：有时是有线或虚拟网卡
  • lo0：本地回环（127.0.0.1）

只看 Wi-Fi：

ifconfig en0

docs.title: 2️⃣ 查看当前 IP 地址（推荐）
docs.text:
ipconfig getifaddr en0

查看所有接口 IP：

ipconfig getifaddr en0
ipconfig getifaddr en1

docs.title: 3️⃣ 查看路由表（是否有默认网关）
docs.text:
netstat -rn

关键一行：

default            192.168.1.1

没有 default → 网络通常无法访问外网。

docs.title: 4️⃣ 查看当前网络配置（官方工具）
docs.text:
scutil --nwi

可看到：

  • 当前使用的接口
  • DNS / IPv4 / IPv6 状态
  • 是否联网（Reachable）

docs.title: 三、Wi-Fi 专用查看（macOS 特有）
5️⃣ 查看 Wi-Fi 连接信息（信号、速率）
docs.text:
/System/Library/PrivateFrameworks/Apple80211.framework/Versions/Current/Resources/airport -I

重点字段：

  • SSID：当前 Wi-Fi 名称
  • agrCtlRSSI：信号强度（-30 很好，-80 很差）
  • lastTxRate：当前速率

docs.title: 6️⃣ 扫描附近 Wi-Fi
docs.text: /System/Library/PrivateFrameworks/Apple80211.framework/Versions/Current/Resources/airport -s

docs.title: 四、连通性测试（非常关键）
7️⃣ 测试局域网
docs.text: ping 192.168.1.1

docs.title: 8️⃣ 测试公网
docs.text: ping 8.8.8.8

docs.title: 9️⃣ 测试 DNS 是否正常
docs.text:
ping www.baidu.com

👉 能 ping IP，不能 ping 域名 = DNS 问题

docs.title: 🔟 查看当前 DNS
docs.text:
scutil --dns

或简洁版：

networksetup -getdnsservers Wi-Fi

docs.title: 六、查看当前连接和端口
1️⃣1️⃣ 查看当前 TCP/UDP 连接
docs.text: netstat -an

docs.title: 1️⃣2️⃣ 查看监听端口（配合进程）
docs.text:
lsof -i -n -P

例如：

lsof -i :22

docs.title: 七、网络诊断一条龙（强烈推荐）
1️⃣3️⃣ macOS 自带诊断
docs.text:
networkQuality

（macOS Monterey+）

显示：

  • 上行 / 下行带宽
  • 延迟
  • 响应质量（很好用）

docs.title: pbcopy & pbpaste
docs.text: pbpaste 是 macOS 系统中用于与剪贴板（Clipboard）交互的命令行工具，它可以让你在终端中读取剪贴板中的内容。

docs.title: 功能
docs.text:
• 从系统剪贴板读取文本并输出到标准输出（通常是终端）。

  • 常用于脚本中提取剪贴板内容以进一步处理。

docs.title: 基本用法
docs.text:
pbpaste

这将把当前剪贴板中的文本内容输出到终端。

docs.title: 1. 将剪贴板内容保存到文件
docs.text: pbpaste > output.txt

docs.title: 2. 把剪贴板内容传给其他命令处理（例如统计行数）
docs.text: pbpaste | wc -l

docs.title: 3. 使用剪贴板内容作为命令参数
docs.text: grep "$(pbpaste)" somefile.txt

docs.title: 简介
docs.text: • pbcopy 是与 pbpaste 相对的命令，用于将标准输入的文本写入剪贴板。

docs.title: 示例用法
docs.text:
echo "Hello, clipboard!" | pbcopy

然后你可以通过粘贴操作（Cmd + V）或者用 pbpaste 检查：

pbpaste
# 输出：Hello, clipboard!

docs.title: 剪贴板内容去重并排序
docs.text: pbpaste | sort | uniq | pbcopy

docs.title: 将某个文件内容复制到剪贴板
docs.text: cat somefile.txt | pbcopy

docs.title: 注意事项
docs.text:
• pbpaste 和 pbcopy 只能处理 纯文本 内容（不能处理图像、富文本等）。

  • 它们主要用于 交互式用户剪贴板（GUI 环境），不能在 SSH 会话下使用，除非通过 GUI 共享剪贴板。

docs.title: 总结
docs.text: 命令 作用 pbpaste 从剪贴板读取文本内容 pbcopy 将文本写入剪贴板

docs.title: 1. What Is a Shell?
docs.text:
A shell is a program that lets you interact with macOS using text commands instead of clicking buttons.

  • You type commands
  • The shell executes them
  • You get text output

On macOS, you access the shell through Terminal.app.

Think of the shell as: You → Shell → Operating System

docs.title: Method 1: Spotlight (Recommended)
docs.text:
1. Press ⌘ Command + Space
  2. Type Terminal
  3. Press Enter

docs.title: Method 2: Finder
docs.text: Applications → Utilities → Terminal

docs.title: 3. Common Shells on macOS
docs.text:
macOS supports multiple shells.

Shell Description zsh Default shell since macOS Catalina (10.15+) bash Older default (still widely used) sh Original Unix shell (minimal) fish User-friendly, needs installation

docs.title: Check your current shell
docs.text:
echo $SHELL

Example output:

/bin/zsh

docs.title: 4.1 Where am I?
docs.text:
pwd

Prints the current directory.

docs.title: 4.2 List files
docs.text:
ls
ls -l
ls -a
Command Meaning ls List files ls -l Long format ls -a Include hidden files

docs.title: 4.3 Change directory
docs.text:
cd Documents
cd ..
cd ~
Path Meaning .. Parent directory ~ Home directory

docs.title: 4.4 Create & remove files
docs.text:
touch test.txt
rm test.txt

Create / delete directories:

mkdir mydir
rmdir mydir

docs.title: 4.5 View file contents
docs.text:
cat file.txt
less file.txt
  • less allows scrolling (press q to quit)

docs.title: 5. Command Structure
docs.text:
A shell command usually looks like:

command options arguments

Example:

ls -l /Applications
  • ls → command
  • -l → option
  • /Applications → argument

docs.title: 6. Useful Keyboard Shortcuts
docs.text: Shortcut Function ↑ / ↓ Command history Tab Auto-completion Ctrl + C Stop command Ctrl + D Exit shell Cmd + K Clear terminal screen

docs.title: 7. Environment Variables
docs.text: Shells use environment variables.

docs.title: View all variables
docs.text: env

docs.title: View one variable
docs.text:
echo $PATH

PATH tells the shell where to find commands.

docs.title: 8. Shell Configuration Files (Very Important)
docs.text: Your shell behavior is controlled by config files.

docs.title: For zsh (default)
docs.text: File Purpose ~/.zshrc Main config (most used) ~/.zprofile Login shell settings

docs.title: For bash
docs.text:
File ~/.bashrc ~/.bash_profile

Edit with:

nano ~/.zshrc

Apply changes:

source ~/.zshrc

docs.title: 9. How to Change Your Default Shell
9.1 List available shells
docs.text: cat /etc/shells

docs.title: 9.2 Change shell using chsh
docs.text:
chsh -s /bin/zsh # -s: switch

Or switch to bash:

chsh -s /bin/bash

You must log out and back in for it to take effect.

docs.title: 9.3 Temporary shell switch
docs.text:
Run another shell inside the current one:

bash
zsh
sh

Exit with:

exit

docs.title: 10. zsh vs bash (macOS Perspective)
docs.text:
Feature zsh bash Default on macOS ✅ ❌ Better completion ✅ ⚠️ Plugin ecosystem Excellent Good Compatibility High Very high

Recommendation: 👉 Stick with zsh unless you have a specific reason.

docs.title: Oh My Zsh (Popular)
docs.text:
sh -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ohmyzsh/ohmyzsh/master/tools/install.sh)"

Adds:

  • Git status
  • Themes
  • Plugins

Beginner-friendly and widely used on macOS.

docs.title: 12. Common Beginner Mistakes
docs.text: ❌ Running Linux-only commands on macOS ❌ Editing /etc/* files unnecessarily ❌ Using sudo blindly ❌ Deleting files with rm -rf without understanding

docs.title: 13. Summary
docs.text:
• A shell is a text interface to macOS
  • zsh is the default and recommended shell
  • Learn basic commands: ls, cd, pwd, cat
  • Customize behavior via ~/.zshrc
  • Change shells using chsh

docs.title: 1. What Is Breed?
docs.text:
Breed is a third-party bootloader commonly used on embedded routers (especially MediaTek / MTK devices).

Think of it as the router equivalent of a PC BIOS/UEFI, but much more powerful and user-friendly.

docs.title: What Breed can do
docs.text:
• Flash OpenWrt / LEDE / stock firmware
  • Backup and restore router partitions
  • Recover a bricked router
  • Flash firmware via a web browser
  • Manage kernel, rootfs, and full firmware images

docs.title: Why people like Breed
docs.text:
• Web-based (no serial cable required)
  • Much safer than vendor bootloaders
  • Ideal for firmware developers and beginners

docs.title: 2. When Do You Need Breed?
docs.text:
You typically use Breed when you want to:

  • Install OpenWrt / LEDE
  • Recover from a failed firmware flash
  • Switch between official firmware and OpenWrt
  • Experiment with custom builds

If you already use OpenWrt daily, Breed is your safety net.

docs.title: 3. What Is “Breed (Web)”?
docs.text:
Breed supports multiple access methods, but the most common is:

Breed Web UI – a small web page hosted by the bootloader itself

This allows you to:

  • Open a browser
  • Upload firmware
  • Flash safely
  • No command line needed

docs.title: 4. Supported Devices (Important!)
docs.text:
Breed is device-specific.

Before using Breed, you must confirm:

  • Your router model
  • Your SoC (CPU)

docs.title: Common supported platforms
docs.text:
• MediaTek MT7620 / MT7621 / MT7628
  • MT7981 / MT7986 (some newer devices)
  • Many Xiaomi, GL.iNet, Newifi routers

⚠️ Never flash a Breed image for another model.

docs.title: 5. How Breed Works (Simple Explanation)
docs.text:
Boot sequence:

Power on
 ↓
Breed bootloader
 ↓
Firmware (OpenWrt / Stock)

Breed runs before the firmware, so even if the firmware is broken, Breed still works.

docs.title: 6. How to Enter Breed Web Mode
Method 1: Hardware Reset Button (Most Common)
docs.text:
1. Power off the router
  2. Press and hold the RESET button
  3. Power on the router
  4. Keep holding RESET for 5–10 seconds
  5. Release the button

If successful:

  • Router does not boot normally
  • Breed Web UI becomes active

docs.title: Method 2: From OpenWrt (If Installed)
docs.text:
Some routers allow entering Breed via command:

reboot

Then hold RESET immediately during reboot.

(Exact behavior depends on device.)

docs.title: Step 1: Set Your Computer IP
docs.text:
Breed usually uses a static IP, commonly:

Router (Breed): 192.168.1.1

Set your PC manually:

Setting Value IP 192.168.1.2 Netmask 255.255.255.0 Gateway (leave empty)

docs.title: Step 2: Connect via Ethernet
docs.text:
• Use a LAN cable
  • Connect PC → router LAN port
  • Wi-Fi usually does NOT work in Breed mode

docs.title: Step 3: Open the Web Page
docs.text:
Open browser and visit:

http://192.168.1.1

If successful, you will see:

Breed Web Recovery Console

docs.title: 8. Breed Web Interface Overview
docs.text: Typical sections include:

docs.title: 1. Firmware Update
docs.text:
• Flash full firmware
  • Flash kernel or rootfs separately

docs.title: 2. Partition Management
docs.text:
• View flash layout
  • Backup partitions
  • Restore partitions

docs.title: 3. System Info
docs.text:
• Flash size
  • RAM
  • CPU info

docs.title: 4. Environment Variables
docs.text:
• Boot arguments
  • Advanced users only

docs.title: 9. Flashing Firmware Using Breed (Beginner Safe Way)
Step 1: Prepare Firmware
docs.text:
• Download correct firmware for your router
  • Usually a .bin file
  • Prefer sysupgrade or factory image as recommended

docs.title: Step 2: Upload Firmware
docs.text:
In Breed Web UI:

  1. Go to Firmware Update
  2. Choose firmware file
  3. Select Full Flash (recommended for beginners)
  4. Click Upload

docs.title: Step 3: Flash and Reboot
docs.text:
• Wait patiently (1–3 minutes)
  • Do NOT power off
  • Router reboots automatically

docs.title: 10. Backup Before Flashing (Highly Recommended)
docs.text:
Before flashing anything:

  1. Open Partition Backup
  2. Backup:
    • Bootloader
    • Factory
    • EEPROM / ART
  3. Save files to your PC

These backups can save your router forever.

docs.title: 11. Common IP Addresses Used by Breed
docs.text:
IP Usage 192.168.1.1 Most common 192.168.0.1 Some devices 192.168.99.1 Rare

Check your router documentation if unsure.

docs.title: Cannot open 192.168.1.1
docs.text:
• Check PC IP configuration
  • Disable Wi-Fi
  • Try another LAN port
  • Try another browser

docs.title: Flash fails
docs.text:
• Wrong firmware image
  • Mismatched flash layout
  • Try full flash instead of partial

docs.title: Router boot loops
docs.text:
• Enter Breed again
  • Restore backup
  • Flash known-good firmware

docs.title: 13. Safety Rules (Very Important)
docs.text: ✅ Always use firmware for your exact model ✅ Always backup partitions first ❌ Never flash bootloader unless required ❌ Never interrupt power during flashing

docs.title: 14. Breed vs U-Boot (Simple Comparison)
docs.text: Feature Breed Stock U-Boot Web UI ✅ ❌ Easy recovery ✅ ❌ Beginner friendly ✅ ❌ Brick risk Low High

docs.title: 15. Summary
docs.text:
• Breed is a powerful router bootloader
  • Breed Web UI makes flashing firmware easy
  • It is the best recovery tool for OpenWrt users
  • Learn it once, save your router many times

docs.title: ImmortalWrt
docs.text:

  • https://firmware-selector.immortalwrt.org/

docs.title: 1. What Is ImmortalWrt?
docs.text:
ImmortalWrt is a community-driven fork of OpenWrt.

In simple terms:

ImmortalWrt = OpenWrt + more features + faster updates + router-user focus

docs.title: Key characteristics
docs.text:
• Based on OpenWrt source code
  • Maintains additional patches and features
  • Often includes more LuCI apps and kernel modules
  • Popular among users in China / Asia
  • Actively maintained

If OpenWrt is the official upstream, ImmortalWrt is a feature-rich downstream distribution.

docs.title: 2. ImmortalWrt vs OpenWrt (Beginner View)
docs.text:
Feature OpenWrt ImmortalWrt Official project ✅ ❌ (fork) Stability Very high High Release speed Slower Faster Built-in packages Minimal More LuCI apps Basic Rich Beginner friendly Medium High Community support Global Asia-focused

For beginners, ImmortalWrt often feels:

  • Easier to use
  • Less manual package installation
  • Better “out of the box”

docs.title: Recommended if:
docs.text:
• You want easy setup
  • You plan to use:
    • Proxy tools (PassWall / SSR Plus / OpenClash)
    • USB storage
    • NAS / file sharing
  • Your router is low-end or mid-range
  • You don’t want to compile everything yourself

docs.title: Not recommended if:
docs.text:
• You need official OpenWrt certification
  • You develop upstream OpenWrt code
  • You want the purest minimal system

docs.title: 4. Supported Devices
docs.text: ImmortalWrt supports most OpenWrt-supported devices, plus some extras.

docs.title: Common platforms
docs.text:
• MediaTek (MT7621 / MT7981 / MT7986)
  • Qualcomm IPQ
  • x86_64
  • Some older MIPS devices

⚠️ Always check device model carefully Different hardware revisions = different firmware

docs.title: 5. Firmware Types Explained (Very Important)
docs.text: When downloading ImmortalWrt firmware, you will see several files.

docs.title: Common filenames
docs.text:
immortalwrt-23.05.1-xxx-sysupgrade.bin
immortalwrt-23.05.1-xxx-factory.bin

docs.title: What do they mean?
docs.text:
File Purpose factory.bin Flash from stock firmware sysupgrade.bin Upgrade from OpenWrt / ImmortalWrt

❗ Flashing the wrong one may brick your router.

docs.title: 6. Flashing ImmortalWrt (General Process)
docs.text: The exact steps vary by router, but the logic is always the same.

docs.title: Method 1: From stock firmware (Web UI)
docs.text:
1. Login to stock router page
  2. Firmware upgrade
  3. Upload factory.bin
  4. Wait patiently (do NOT power off)

docs.title: Method 2: From OpenWrt / ImmortalWrt
docs.text:
1. Login to LuCI
  2. System → Backup / Flash Firmware
  3. Upload sysupgrade.bin
  4. Choose:
    • Keep settings ❌ (recommended OFF for beginners)
  5. Flash and reboot

docs.title: 7. First Boot: What You Should Do
docs.text:
After flashing, ImmortalWrt will usually use:

  • IP: 192.168.1.1
  • No password

docs.title: Step 1: Set root password
docs.text: System → Administration

docs.title: Step 2: Configure WAN
docs.text:
Network → Interfaces → WAN

Common types:

  • DHCP (most home networks)
  • PPPoE (ISP username/password)

docs.title: 8. LuCI Interface Overview
docs.text: ImmortalWrt uses LuCI, the web UI.

docs.title: Main menus beginners care about
docs.text:
• Status – system info
  • Network – LAN / WAN / Wi-Fi
  • System – password, timezone, upgrade
  • Services – proxy, VPN, NAS, etc.

ImmortalWrt usually includes more items under “Services” than OpenWrt.

docs.title: 9. Package Management (opkg)
docs.text: ImmortalWrt uses the same package system as OpenWrt.

docs.title: Update package list
docs.text: opkg update

docs.title: Install a package
docs.text: opkg install htop

docs.title: Remove a package
docs.text:
opkg remove htop

💡 ImmortalWrt often ships with:

  • More kernel modules
  • Common LuCI apps pre-enabled

docs.title: 10. ImmortalWrt Software Ecosystem
docs.text:
Popular built-in or available features:

  • PassWall / SSR Plus
  • OpenClash
  • USB storage & automount
  • Samba / FTP
  • WireGuard / OpenVPN
  • Ad blocking
  • QoS / SQM

This is one reason beginners prefer ImmortalWrt.

docs.title: Safe upgrade rules
docs.text:
• Always use sysupgrade.bin
  • Backup configs first
  • Major version upgrade → do NOT keep settings
  • Read changelog before upgrading

docs.title: Recommended
docs.text:
• Stay on stable releases
  • Avoid daily snapshots unless you know what you’re doing

docs.title: 12. Common Beginner Mistakes
docs.text:
❌ Flashing wrong firmware file

❌ Mixing OpenWrt and ImmortalWrt feeds

❌ Forcing opkg installs (-f)

❌ Ignoring storage size limits

❌ Power-off during flashing

docs.title: 13. ImmortalWrt vs LEDE vs OpenWrt (Quick Summary)
docs.text:
• OpenWrt → official, clean, minimal
  • ImmortalWrt → feature-rich, beginner-friendly
  • LEDE → legacy (now merged into OpenWrt)

👉 For learning and daily home use: ImmortalWrt is an excellent starting point

docs.title: 14. Learning Path Recommendation
docs.text:
For beginners:

  1. Learn LuCI basics
  2. Understand interfaces & firewall
  3. Practice opkg
  4. Add one service at a time
  5. Learn sysupgrade & recovery

docs.title: OpenWrt: Notes
docs.text:

docs.title: 1. What Is OpenWrt?
docs.text:
OpenWrt is an open-source embedded Linux operating system designed mainly for routers and network devices.

Unlike stock router firmware (from TP-Link, Xiaomi, ASUS, etc.), OpenWrt is:

  • A full Linux system
  • Highly customizable
  • Regularly updated
  • Designed for advanced networking

You can think of OpenWrt as:

“Ubuntu for routers”

docs.title: 2.1 Limitations of Stock Router Firmware
docs.text:
Most factory firmware:

  • Has limited features
  • Cannot install extra software
  • Is rarely updated
  • Locks advanced configuration

docs.title: 2.2 Advantages of OpenWrt
docs.text:
OpenWrt gives you:

  • ✅ Full control over routing, firewall, Wi-Fi
  • ✅ Package manager (opkg)
  • ✅ SSH access
  • ✅ Advanced features:
    • VLAN
    • VPN (WireGuard / OpenVPN)
    • QoS / SQM
    • Ad-blocking
    • Mesh networking
  • ✅ Long-term community support

docs.title: Key Components
docs.text: Component Purpose LuCI Web management interface opkg Package manager BusyBox Core Linux utilities netifd Network management procd Init system

docs.title: 4. Supported Devices
docs.text:
OpenWrt runs on:

  • Home routers
  • Travel routers
  • Mini PCs
  • Virtual machines
  • Raspberry Pi

docs.title: Check Compatibility
docs.text:
Always check:

https://openwrt.org/toh/start

Look for:

  • Flash size
  • RAM size
  • Supported version
  • Installation method

docs.title: 5.1 Common Installation Methods
docs.text:
Method When Used Web upgrade Stock firmware supports it TFTP Recovery mode Serial console Advanced / bricked devices SD card Raspberry Pi

⚠️ Installing the wrong firmware can brick your router.

docs.text: After installation:

docs.title: 6.1 Default Access
docs.text:
• IP address: 192.168.1.1
  • Username: root
  • Password: (empty)

docs.title: 6.2 First Things to Do
docs.text:
1. Set root password
  2. Configure WAN
  3. Enable Wi-Fi
  4. Update package list

docs.title: 7. LuCI Web Interface
docs.text: LuCI is OpenWrt’s web UI.

docs.title: Key Sections
docs.text:
Menu Description Status System & network status Network Interfaces, Wi-Fi, DHCP System Time, users, startup Services Installed services Firewall Zones, rules, NAT

LuCI makes OpenWrt usable without command-line knowledge.

docs.text: Command Purpose opkg update Update package list opkg install xxx Install package opkg list-installed List packages reboot Reboot system logread View system logs

docs.title: 9. Package Management with opkg
docs.text: OpenWrt uses opkg, similar to apt or yum.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
opkg update

Common packages:

  • luci-app-wireguard
  • luci-app-openvpn
  • luci-app-adblock
