docs.title: Interfaces
docs.text:
OpenWrt uses logical interfaces:

  • LAN
  • WAN
  • WAN6

Each interface includes:

  • Protocol (DHCP, PPPoE, Static)
  • Firewall zone
  • Physical device

docs.title: Wi-Fi
docs.text:
Wi-Fi is disabled by default after installation. You must:

  1. Set SSID
  2. Set encryption
  3. Enable radio

docs.title: 11. Firewall Concept (Very Important)
docs.text: OpenWrt firewall is zone-based.

docs.title: Common Zones
docs.text:
Zone Purpose LAN Trusted internal network WAN Untrusted internet

Default rule:

LAN → WAN : allowed
WAN → LAN : blocked

This provides strong security by default.

docs.title: 12. Common Use Cases
docs.text:
OpenWrt is often used for:

  • Home router replacement
  • VPN gateway
  • Ad-blocking router
  • Smart home network isolation
  • Campus / dorm networking
  • Learning networking & Linux

docs.title: 13. When OpenWrt Is NOT Recommended
docs.text:
Avoid OpenWrt if:

  • Your router has very small flash (<8MB)
  • You only want “plug and play”
  • You are afraid of troubleshooting

docs.title: 14. Learning Path Recommendation
docs.text:
For beginners:

  1. Learn LuCI basics
  2. Understand WAN / LAN
  3. Learn opkg
  4. Try SSH
  5. Configure VPN
  6. Learn firewall rules

docs.title: 15. Summary
docs.text:
OpenWrt is:

  • A powerful Linux-based router OS
  • Highly flexible and customizable
  • Ideal for learning networking
  • Best for users who want control

If you know basic Linux, OpenWrt will feel very natural.

docs.title: 1. What Is OpenWrt Compilation?
docs.text:
OpenWrt compilation means:

  • Downloading OpenWrt source code
  • Selecting your router model and features
  • Building (compiling) a custom firmware image
  • Flashing it onto your router

Why compile OpenWrt yourself?

  • Add or remove packages (e.g. LuCI apps, VPN tools)
  • Optimize for your hardware
  • Fix missing packages in official images
  • Learn how OpenWrt really works (huge bonus)

docs.title: Hardware
docs.text:
• A Linux machine (Ubuntu 20.04 / 22.04 recommended)
  • At least:
    • 4 GB RAM (8 GB+ recommended)
    • 20–30 GB disk space
  • Internet connection

macOS and WSL can work, but native Linux is strongly recommended for beginners.

docs.title: 3. Install Build Dependencies
docs.text:
On Ubuntu:

sudo apt update
sudo apt install -y \
  build-essential clang flex bison g++ gawk gcc-multilib \
  gettext git libncurses-dev libssl-dev python3-distutils \
  rsync unzip zlib1g-dev file wget

⚠️ Missing dependencies are the #1 reason compilation fails.

docs.title: 4. Download OpenWrt Source Code
docs.text:
Go to a working directory:

mkdir -p ~/openwrt
cd ~/openwrt

Clone the official repository:

git clone https://github.com/openwrt/openwrt.git
cd openwrt

Checkout a stable release (recommended for beginners):

git checkout openwrt-23.05

docs.title: 5. Update and Install Feeds
docs.text:
Feeds are package sources (LuCI, network tools, etc.).

./scripts/feeds update -a
./scripts/feeds install -a

If you see warnings here, they’re usually safe unless they mention missing core packages.

docs.title: 6. Configure the Build (menuconfig)
docs.text:
Run:

make menuconfig

This is the most important step.

docs.title: 6.1 Target System
docs.text:
Choose your CPU architecture, for example:

  • MediaTek
  • Qualcomm Atheros
  • x86

docs.title: 6.2 Subtarget
docs.text: Specific SoC family (e.g. MT7621, IPQ807x)

docs.title: 6.3 Target Profile
docs.text:
Your exact router model

If your model is listed, always select it.

docs.title: 6.4 LuCI (Web UI)
docs.text:
Enable LuCI:

LuCI  --->
  Collections  --->
    <*> luci

Optional but recommended:

  • luci-ssl (HTTPS)
  • luci-app-firewall
  • luci-app-opkg

docs.title: 6.5 Common Useful Packages
docs.text:
Examples:

Network  --->
  <*> wget
  <*> curl

Utilities  --->
  <*> htop

💡 Don’t select too many packages at first.

docs.title: Save and Exit
docs.text:
• Press Save
  • Exit menuconfig

Your config is saved to .config.

docs.title: First Build (slow!)
docs.text:
make -j$(nproc)
  • First build can take 30–120 minutes
  • CPU will be at 100% — that’s normal

If it fails:

make -j1 V=s

This gives detailed error logs.

docs.title: 8. Where Is the Firmware?
docs.text:
After success:

ls bin/targets/

Example path:

bin/targets/mediatek/mt7621/

You’ll find:

  • *-factory.bin → Flash from vendor firmware
  • *-sysupgrade.bin → Upgrade from existing OpenWrt

docs.title: From Stock Firmware
docs.text:
• Use router’s web UI
  • Upload factory.bin

docs.title: From OpenWrt
docs.text:
sysupgrade your-firmware-sysupgrade.bin

⚠️ Double-check:

  • Correct router model
  • Correct target Wrong firmware = soft brick.

docs.title: Clean build files (safe)
docs.text: make clean

docs.title: Full reset (slow)
docs.text: make dirclean

docs.title: Reconfigure
docs.text:
make menuconfig
make -j$(nproc)

docs.title: ❌ Missing dependency
docs.text:
Solution:

sudo apt install <missing-package>

docs.title: ❌ Feeds warning
docs.text:
Usually OK unless:

  • host dependency does not exist
  • package not found

docs.title: ❌ Out of memory
docs.text:
• Reduce jobs:
make -j2
  • Add swap

docs.title: 12. Recommended Learning Path
docs.text:
1. Compile official OpenWrt with LuCI only
  2. Add small packages (htop, curl)
  3. Add VPN / proxy tools
  4. Learn to:
    • Create custom packages
    • Modify .config
    • Patch source code

docs.title: 13. Useful Commands Cheat Sheet
docs.text:
make menuconfig      # Configure
make -j$(nproc)      # Build
make clean           # Clean build
./scripts/feeds update -a
./scripts/feeds install -a

docs.title: opkg
docs.text: opkg is the package manager in OpenWrt, similar to apt on Debian/Ubuntu or yum on CentOS. It allows you to install, remove, update, and manage software packages on your router.

docs.title: 1. Checking if opkg is available
docs.text:
On your OpenWrt router, open SSH and type:

opkg --help

If opkg is installed, you’ll see a list of commands and options.

docs.title: 2. Updating package lists
docs.text:
Before installing anything, always update the list of available packages:

opkg update
  • This downloads the latest package information from OpenWrt repositories.
  • Important: Run this every time you want to install new software to ensure you get the latest version.

docs.title: 3. Searching for packages
docs.text:
You can search for packages by name or description:

opkg list | grep <keyword>

Example: search for usb packages:

opkg list | grep usb
  • opkg list shows all packages.
  • grep usb filters the list to only lines containing usb.

docs.title: 4. Installing a package
docs.text:
To install a package:

opkg install <package-name>

Example: install USB support:

opkg install kmod-usb-storage
  • Most OpenWrt packages have dependencies. opkg will install them automatically.
  • Some common packages:
    • luci – Web interface
    • kmod-usb-storage – USB storage support
    • nano – Lightweight text editor

docs.title: 5. Removing a package
docs.text:
To remove a package you no longer need:

opkg remove <package-name>

Example:

opkg remove nano
  • Use --force-depends if you need to remove a package that is required by another (use carefully!).

docs.title: 6. Upgrading packages
docs.text:
To upgrade all installed packages:

opkg list-upgradable       # List packages that can be upgraded
opkg upgrade               # Upgrade them

⚠️ Warning: Upgrading all packages on a router with limited flash storage can sometimes fail. Upgrade selectively if needed.

docs.title: 7. Showing package info
docs.text:
To check details about a package:

opkg info <package-name>

Example:

opkg info kmod-usb-storage

This shows version, description, dependencies, and installed status.

docs.title: 8. Advanced tips
docs.text:
1. Saving storage space

    • OpenWrt routers have limited flash. Check installed packages:
    opkg list-installed

  2. Working with feeds

    • Some packages require extra feeds. Feeds are additional sources of packages.
    • Configure in /etc/opkg/customfeeds.conf.

  3. Installing packages from .ipk files

    • You can download .ipk files and install locally:
    opkg install /tmp/mypackage.ipk

docs.title: 9. Example Workflow: USB + SD Card Support
docs.text:
1. Update package list:
opkg update
  1. Install kernel modules for USB & SD cards:
opkg install kmod-usb-storage kmod-fs-ext4 block-mount
  1. Install utilities for mounting:
opkg install mount-utils fdisk lsblk
  1. Verify:
ls /dev/sd*

docs.title: 10. Summary of Common opkg Commands
docs.text: Command Purpose opkg update Update package list opkg list List all available packages opkg list-installed List installed packages opkg install <pkg> Install a package opkg remove <pkg> Remove a package opkg info <pkg> Show package info opkg upgrade Upgrade installed packages opkg list-upgradable List upgradable packages

docs.title: 1. What Is Raspberry Pi OS?
docs.text:
Raspberry Pi OS (formerly called Raspbian) is the official operating system for Raspberry Pi computers.

It is:

  • Free and open-source
  • Based on Debian Linux
  • Optimized specifically for Raspberry Pi hardware
  • Designed for learning, programming, and everyday use

If you are new to Raspberry Pi or Linux, Raspberry Pi OS is the best starting choice.

docs.title: 2. Why Choose Raspberry Pi OS?
docs.text:
For beginners, Raspberry Pi OS is popular because:

  • ✅ Officially supported by the Raspberry Pi Foundation
  • ✅ Large community and tutorials
  • ✅ Lightweight and fast on Pi hardware
  • ✅ Comes with useful preinstalled tools
  • ✅ Very stable

Typical use cases:

  • Learning Linux basics
  • Programming (Python, C/C++)
  • Networking and servers
  • Robotics and electronics
  • Home projects (NAS, Pi-hole, smart home)

docs.title: 3. Raspberry Pi OS Editions
docs.text: Raspberry Pi OS comes in three main versions:

docs.title: 1️⃣ Raspberry Pi OS (64-bit / 32-bit) with Desktop
docs.text:
• Graphical desktop (similar to Windows/macOS)
  • Best for beginners
  • Recommended if you use a monitor

docs.title: 2️⃣ Raspberry Pi OS Lite
docs.text:
• No graphical interface (command line only)
  • Uses less memory
  • Ideal for servers and headless setups

docs.title: 3️⃣ Raspberry Pi OS with Desktop and Recommended Software
docs.text:
• Desktop + many extra apps
  • Good for education, but larger size

👉 Beginner recommendation: Raspberry Pi OS (64-bit) with Desktop

docs.title: 4. Basic System Requirements
docs.text:
You will need:

  • Raspberry Pi (Pi 3, 4, or 5 recommended)
  • microSD card (16 GB or larger)
  • Power supply
  • (Optional) Monitor, keyboard, mouse
  • (Optional) Network cable or Wi-Fi

docs.title: Step 1: Download Raspberry Pi Imager
docs.text:
• Available for Windows, macOS, and Linux
  • Official tool for flashing OS to SD card

docs.title: Step 2: Flash the OS
docs.text:
1. Insert microSD card into your computer
  2. Open Raspberry Pi Imager
  3. Choose:
    • Device → your Raspberry Pi model
    • OS → Raspberry Pi OS
    • Storage → your SD card
  4. Click Write

docs.title: Step 3: First Boot
docs.text:
• Insert the SD card into the Raspberry Pi
  • Power it on
  • Follow the on-screen setup (language, Wi-Fi, password)

docs.title: 6. The Raspberry Pi OS Desktop
docs.text:
The desktop environment is called PIXEL.

Main components:

  • Top panel: menus, network, sound, clock
  • Desktop icons: Home folder, Trash
  • File Manager: manage files like Finder / Explorer
  • Terminal: command-line interface

You can use the system fully with the mouse, but learning the terminal is strongly recommended.

docs.title: 7. Understanding the File System
docs.text:
Raspberry Pi OS uses a Linux file structure.

Important directories:

  • /home/pi or /home/username → your personal files
  • /etc → system configuration
  • /usr → installed software
  • /var → logs and variable data

Your daily work should stay inside:

/home/yourname

docs.title: 8. Using the Terminal (Very Important)
docs.text:
Open Terminal from the menu.

Common beginner commands:

pwd        # show current directory
ls         # list files
cd folder  # change directory
mkdir test # create folder
rm file    # delete file

Update the system:

sudo apt update
sudo apt upgrade

Install software:

sudo apt install vim

docs.title: Check IP address
docs.text: ip a

docs.title: Test network
docs.text: ping google.com

docs.title: Enable SSH (remote login)
docs.text:
sudo raspi-config
  • Interface Options → SSH → Enable

Then connect from another computer:

ssh username@pi_ip_address

docs.title: 10. Programming on Raspberry Pi OS
docs.text:
Raspberry Pi OS is great for learning programming.

Preinstalled or easily available:

  • Python (default language)
  • C / C++
  • Scratch
  • Node.js

Example Python test:

python3
print("Hello Raspberry Pi")

docs.title: 11. Updating and Maintaining the System
docs.text:
Regular maintenance:

sudo apt update
sudo apt upgrade
sudo reboot

Check disk usage:

df -h

docs.title: 12. Common Beginner Mistakes
docs.text:
• ❌ Removing system files with sudo rm
  • ❌ Forgetting passwords
  • ❌ Using random commands from the internet
  • ❌ Powering off without shutdown

Correct shutdown:

sudo shutdown now

docs.title: 13. When to Use Raspberry Pi OS Lite
docs.text:
Choose Lite if:

  • No monitor is attached
  • You only use SSH
  • You want better performance
  • You build servers or services

docs.title: 14. Raspberry Pi OS vs Other Systems
docs.text: System Best For Raspberry Pi OS Beginners, learning Ubuntu Server Cloud, servers Ubuntu Desktop Familiar UI OpenWrt Routers, networking RetroPie Gaming

docs.title: 15. Next Steps After Installation
docs.text:
Good things to learn next:

  • Linux permissions (chmod, chown)
  • SSH and SCP
  • System services (systemctl)
  • Networking basics
  • Shell scripting

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Raspberry Pi OS is:

  • Beginner-friendly
  • Powerful enough for real projects
  • A great way to learn Linux and computing

docs.title: 1. What Is VNC?
docs.text:
VNC (Virtual Network Computing) lets you control your Raspberry Pi’s desktop remotely from another computer (Windows, macOS, or Linux) over the network.

Raspberry Pi OS includes RealVNC Server by default, so no extra installation is usually needed.

docs.title: 2. Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before starting, make sure:

  • Raspberry Pi is running Raspberry Pi OS (with desktop)
  • Raspberry Pi is connected to the network (Wi-Fi or Ethernet)
  • You can:
    • Access the Pi locally (monitor + keyboard), or
    • Log in via SSH

docs.title: 3. Enable VNC on Raspberry Pi OS (GUI Method)
Step 1: Open Raspberry Pi Configuration
docs.text:
1. Click the Raspberry Pi menu (top-left)
  2. Select Preferences
  3. Click Raspberry Pi Configuration

docs.title: Step 2: Enable VNC
docs.text:
1. Switch to the Interfaces tab
  2. Find VNC
  3. Select Enable
  4. Click OK

✅ VNC Server is now running.

docs.title: 4. Enable VNC via Command Line (SSH / Terminal Method)
docs.text: If you don’t have a monitor attached, use this method.

docs.title: Step 1: Open Terminal or SSH into Pi
docs.text:
ssh pi@<raspberry-pi-ip>

(Default user may be pi or your custom username.)

docs.title: Step 2: Run Raspberry Pi Configuration Tool
docs.text: sudo raspi-config

docs.title: Step 3: Enable VNC
docs.text:
1. Select Interface Options
  2. Select VNC
  3. Choose Yes
  4. Select OK
  5. Exit

docs.title: 5. Verify VNC Service Status
docs.text:
Check whether the VNC server is running:

systemctl status vncserver-x11-serviced

You should see:

Active: active (running)

If not running, start it manually:

sudo systemctl enable vncserver-x11-serviced
sudo systemctl start vncserver-x11-serviced

docs.title: 6. Find Raspberry Pi IP Address
docs.text: You need the Pi’s IP address to connect.

docs.title: Method 1: From Raspberry Pi
docs.text:
hostname -I

Example output:

192.168.1.120

docs.title: Method 2: From Router
docs.text:
• Log into your router admin page
  • Find DHCP / Connected Devices
  • Look for raspberrypi

docs.title: 7.1 Install VNC Viewer
docs.text:
Download RealVNC Viewer on your client computer:

  • https://www.realvnc.com/en/connect/download/viewer/

Available for:

  • Windows
  • macOS
  • Linux

docs.title: 7.2 Connect to Raspberry Pi
docs.text:
1. Open VNC Viewer

  2. Enter the Pi’s IP address:

    192.168.1.120

  3. Press Enter

  4. Click Continue (security warning is normal)

  5. Enter:

    • Username: Pi username
    • Password: Pi password

🎉 You should now see the Raspberry Pi desktop.

docs.title: Problem 1: Black Screen After Connecting
docs.text:
Cause: No active desktop session.

Fix:

  • Ensure Raspberry Pi OS with desktop is installed

  • Reboot the Pi:

    sudo reboot

docs.title: Problem 2: Connection Refused
docs.text:
Check:

systemctl status vncserver-x11-serviced

If stopped:

sudo systemctl start vncserver-x11-serviced

docs.title: Problem 3: Slow Performance
docs.text:
Suggestions:

  • Use Ethernet instead of Wi-Fi
  • Lower resolution:
    • Raspberry Pi Configuration → Display → Resolution
  • Close unnecessary programs

docs.title: 9. (Optional) Start VNC Automatically on Boot
docs.text:
Usually enabled by default, but you can confirm:

sudo systemctl enable vncserver-x11-serviced

docs.title: 10. Security Tips (Important for Beginners)
docs.text:
• Change default password

    passwd

  • Do NOT expose VNC directly to the internet

  • Use VNC only in local network, or via SSH tunnel

docs.title: 11. Summary
docs.text:
You have learned how to:

  • Enable VNC in Raspberry Pi OS
  • Start and check VNC service
  • Find Raspberry Pi IP address
  • Connect using VNC Viewer
  • Troubleshoot common problems

VNC is one of the easiest ways to manage a Raspberry Pi without a monitor.

docs.title: 1. Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before starting, make sure you have:

  • A Raspberry Pi with Raspberry Pi OS installed
  • An SD card already flashed with Raspberry Pi OS
  • A Wi-Fi network name (SSID) and password
  • Another computer (Windows / macOS / Linux)
  • SSH access to the Raspberry Pi (usually via Ethernet for the first login)

docs.title: 2. Connect to Raspberry Pi via SSH
docs.text:
First, connect the Raspberry Pi to your router using an Ethernet cable.

On your computer, open a terminal and run:

ssh pi@raspberrypi.local

or using IP address:

ssh pi@192.168.1.100

Default credentials (if unchanged):

  • Username: pi
  • Password: raspberry

If SSH is not enabled, create an empty file named ssh in the SD card boot partition before booting.

docs.title: 3. Check Wi-Fi Interface
docs.text:
After logging in, verify that the wireless interface exists:

ip link

You should see something like:

wlan0

If wlan0 is missing, your Pi may not support Wi-Fi or drivers are not loaded.

docs.title: 4. Method 1 (Recommended): Use raspi-config
docs.text:
This is the easiest and safest way for beginners.

Run:

sudo raspi-config

Navigate using arrow keys:

System Options
  └── Wireless LAN

Then:

  1. Enter your Wi-Fi country (important for regulations)
  2. Enter SSID (Wi-Fi name)
  3. Enter Wi-Fi password

Select Finish, then reboot:

sudo reboot

docs.title: 5. Method 2: Configure Wi-Fi Manually (CLI)
docs.text: If you prefer manual configuration or raspi-config is unavailable, follow this method.

docs.title: 5.1 Edit Wi-Fi Configuration File
docs.text:
Open the configuration file:

sudo nano /etc/wpa_supplicant/wpa_supplicant.conf

Add the following at the end:

country=US

network={
    ssid="Your_WiFi_Name"
    psk="Your_WiFi_Password"
}

Replace:

  • US with your country code (e.g. CN, JP, GB)
  • Your_WiFi_Name with your SSID
  • Your_WiFi_Password with your password

Save and exit:

  • Ctrl + O → Enter
  • Ctrl + X

docs.title: 5.2 Restart Network Services
docs.text:
Apply the configuration:

sudo wpa_cli -i wlan0 reconfigure

Or reboot:

sudo reboot

docs.title: 6. Verify Wi-Fi Connection
docs.text:
After reboot, reconnect via Ethernet or Wi-Fi and run:

ip addr show wlan0

If you see an IP address like:

inet 192.168.1.23

🎉 Wi-Fi is working!

You can also test internet connectivity:

ping -c 3 google.com

docs.title: 7. Disable Ethernet (Optional)
docs.text:
Once Wi-Fi is confirmed, you can unplug the Ethernet cable. Find the new IP address via your router or use:

hostname -I

docs.title: ❌ Wi-Fi not connecting
docs.text:
• Check SSID and password spelling

  • Ensure country= is set correctly

  • Try:

    sudo rfkill unblock wifi

docs.title: ❌ No wlan0 interface
docs.text:
• Your Raspberry Pi model may not support Wi-Fi
  • USB Wi-Fi adapter drivers may be missing

docs.title: ❌ Still cannot connect
docs.text:
Check logs:

journalctl -u wpa_supplicant

docs.title: 9. Summary
docs.text: Method Difficulty Recommended raspi-config ⭐ Easy ✅ Yes Manual config ⭐⭐ Medium Optional

docs.text:
